     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he introduced himself to those in the synagogue and attended a meeting</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">he entered into a synagogue</char>. Ref. note of Acts 19:8.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shriveled-up hand…</char>Ref. note of Matt. 12:10|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mobbing him…</char>Lit: <char style="it">falling upon him</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Getting the tar beaten out of them or whatnot</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being flogged</char>.|
                                        |This word means a scourge, a plague, a judgment (perceived at least) from God.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">demonic spirit(s)…</char>Lit: <char style="it">unclean spirit(s)</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Sons of Thunder…</char>means <char style="it">those having a thunderous nature</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bite…</char>Lit: <char style="it">bread</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">neighbors…</char>Lit: <char style="it">those with him</char>. Surmising that “those|
                                        |with him” are his neighbors, since it says later in v. 21 that <char style="it">they came out</char>:|
                                        |assuming that this means they were not in the same house Jesus was in. Some, however, think that “those|
                                        |with him” refers to Jesus’s family members.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">get him under control…</char>Lit: <char style="it">to seize him</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Chief Demon…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Beelzebub</char>. The ancient Jews believed|
                                        |he was the ruler of the demons.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">analogies…</char>Lit: <char style="it">parables</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">How can one demon cast out another demon?</char>…Lit: <char style="it">How can Satan|
                                        |cast out Satan</char>? The demons under Satan at times go by the name of Satan himself, as they do his|
                                        |bidding.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">is divided into parts pitted against each other…</char>Lit: <char style="it">is divided|
                                        |upon itself</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and that’s the end of that…</char>Lit: <char style="it">but instead has an end.</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ornery folk…</char>Lit: <char style="it">sons of men</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">random blasphemies that they blurt out…</char>Lit: …<char style="it">and the blasphemies|
                                        |which they might blaspheme</char>. The wording is a figure of speech.|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He made twelve…</char>Some manuscripts include the phrase, <char style="it">whom he|
                                        |also called “the sent ones” </char>(i.e. apostles) in v. 14 and the phrase, <char style="it">And he made|
                                        |the twelve</char>, in v. 16, but there is not strong evidence whether this is genuine or not. The assumption|
                                        |is that it is not genuine.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">demons…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the demons</char>. In classical Gk., this phrase|
                                        |meant <char style="it">divine visitations, </char>and referred to special talents or powers that select|
                                        |folks had, and also came to mean an inferior race of divine beings. As this evolved in time, it is used|
                                        |in the NT to refer to an evil race of divine beings. This is the meaning Mark selected to use here, by|
                                        |choosing the phrase <char style="it">the demons</char>, which is not used much in the NT,<char style="it">|
                                        |</char>instead of the usual phrase <char style="it">unclean spirits</char>. Mark emphasizes that these|
                                        |evil spirits are an entire supernatural race of a sort. The phrase <char style="it">unclean spirit </char>emphasizes|
                                        |the vile, unnatural, and evil nature of these beings; the phrase <char style="it">the demons </char>emphasizes|
                                        |that these beings are a supernatural race.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Peter</char>…The name comes from a Gk. word means <char style="it">rock</char>. Jesus|
                                        |is not only assigning him this name but declaring that Simon has the characteristics of this new name.|
                                        |Although many interpret <char style="it">rock </char>to mean stability, the meaning of <char style="it">rock|
                                        |</char>as revealed in the NT (ref. Matt 16:18, Eph. 2:20) is a foundation to build upon, which specifically|
                                        |points to a foundational leadership position in the Church. This list of apostles here in Mark 3 ranks|
                                        |them according to the preeminence Jesus assigns to them. Therefore, in listing Peter first and giving|
                                        |him the name Peter (”the rock”), Jesus has made Peter the first among his disciples and the one who’ll|
                                        |lead the early church after his ascension.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">No one can enter the strong man’s house unless he first binds the tough guy</char>…Jesus|
                                        |stated this in the context of the way Satan and his demons operate. This verse is one of the most important|
                                        |rules for understanding how demons take hold of people. What Jesus is saying is that it is not possible|
                                        |for demons to simply approach someone and take control of them, believers and unbelievers alike. In order|
                                        |for evil spirits to get any sort of control over a person, they must break that person’s will first.|
                                        |Breaking their will is “binding the strong man.” Only then, can they “enter the strong man’s house.”|
                                        |A person who is fully demon-possessed has had his willpower systematically broken, and for this reason,|
                                        |someone must cast the demon out of him, since he has not the willpower to do it himself. However, any|
                                        |believer can simply exercise his will and authority in Christ and drive any demonic influence from himself.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">blaspheme the Holy Spirit…</char>Jesus says that this one sin called “the blasphemy|
                                        |of the Holy Spirit” is unforgiveable. Jesus spoke of the same thing in Matt. 12:32 (ref. note there).|
                                        |What exactly, then, is the blasphemy of the Holy Spirit? The answer is in plain sight, as Jesus was insinuating|
                                        |that the Scribes had committed this sin, and what the Scribes did is specified in v.30. Here the Scribes|
                                        |could see the miracles of Jesus, and they attributed them to the devil. Believing in miracles does not|
                                        |require the amount of faith as believing in something which is unseen does. The hardness of heart that|
                                        |denies the undeniable will never turn to God and will therefore never receive forgiveness, ever.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">analogy…</char>Lit: <char style="it">parable(s)</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fall apart</char>…Also: <char style="it">get tripped up</char>; <char style="it">get|
                                        |offended</char>; <char style="it">fall into sin</char>; <char style="it">fall prey to a trap</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">self-delusion…</char>Lit: <char style="it">deceitfulness. </char>Note that the root|
                                        |of <char style="it">deceitfulness</char> <char style="w" strong="G00539">ἀπάτη</char>) is the Gk. verb|
                                        |<char style="it">apataō </char><char style="w" strong="G00538">ἀπατάω</char>) in the active voice means|
                                        |to deceive and mislead but in the middle voice means to “enjoy oneself, live pleasurably” (Danker &amp;|
                                        |Bauer). In this context here in Mark, the noun form acquires some of insinuations of the middle voice.|
                                        |Combined, it means the self-delusion brought on by living a life of pleasure.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">hand-in-hand…</char>Lit: <char style="it">around</char> or <char style="it">surround</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Monitor…</char>Lit: <char style="it">watch</char>; <char style="it">look at</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">see</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The quantity which you deem sufficient is the quantity which will be deemed sufficient|
                                        |for you…</char>Lit: <char style="it">By the measure that you’re measuring, it will be measured to you|
                                        |and will be added to you</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they were dumbfounded with awe and reverence…</char>Lit: <char style="it">they feared|
                                        |a great fear</char>. A figure of speech.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A word to the wise is sufficient</char>…Lit: <char style="it">whoever has an ear to|
                                        |be hearing, let him be hearing</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 11:15.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he sends for the sickle</char>…A textbook-example of a figure of speech. The man does|
                                        |not command that a sickle come (sickles are inanimate), but the worker (or more likely, a several workers)|
                                        |who swings the sickle to come. The definite article <char style="it">the </char>used in <char style="it">the|
                                        |sickle </char>is a key indicator that this is a figure of speech.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I have no beef with you…</char>Lit: <char style="it">what to me and to you</char>. Same|

     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">did for him…</char>Lit: <char style="it">did to him</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">baby…</char>The GT uses the diminutive form of <char style="it">daughter, </char>which|
                                        |can be translated: <char style="it">baby</char>; <char style="it">baby girl; darling daughter; little|
                                        |darling; dear girl; sweet daughter; little girl; precious little daughter; cute little daughter</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">at death’s door</char>…Lit:<char style="it"> is lastly having</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’ll pull through…</char>Lit: <char style="it">I will be saved</char>. In general means:|
                                        |<char style="it">rescued</char>; <char style="it">delivered</char>; <char style="it">kept from catastrophe</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">having one’s life saved;</char> In this context, means: <char style="it">rescued from|
                                        |the living hell of this illness.</char>|

                                        |Jerusalem</char>. Refers to respectable women.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">recuperated entirely…</char>Lit: <char style="it">whole</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they lost it…</char>Lit: <char style="it">they were ecstatic in a great ecstasy</char>.|
                                        |Repetition of <char style="it">ecstasy </char>here is a figure of speech. This is the same type of figure|

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">no one had the ability to chain him up anymore…</char>Lit (Gk. text): <char style="it">oude|
                                        |halusei ouketi oudeis</char>  [which is οὐδὲ ἁλύσει οὐκέτι οὐδεὶς, <char style="w" strong="G03761">οὐδὲ </char>),|
                                        |<char style="w" strong="G00254">ἁλύσει </char>), <char style="w" strong="G03765">οὐκέτι </char>), (οὐδεὶς|
                                        |/Strong’s 3762)], translated lit., <char style="it">neither in chains no longer no one</char>. The close|
                                        |repetition of three similar sounding words, together with the verb tense for <char style="it">able,</char>|
                                        |is an alliteration or assonance. The figure of speech used here paints a picture of multiple men or parties|
                                        |of men making multiple attempts to chain him up, succeeding the first time but failing every time after,|
                                        |but still giving it a go from time to time. This is spelled out in v. 4.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Regiment…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Legion</char>. A roman legion was about 4,000|
                                        |soldiers, closer in size to a modern brigade than a regiment, actually, but being similar as a functional|
                                        |unit.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A woman who had a hemorrhage</char>…<char style="it">hemorrhage</char> …Lit., in v.|
                                        |25: <char style="it">a woman being in a flow of blood twelve years</char>; and lit., in v. 29: <char|
                                        |style="it">her flow of blood dried up</char>. From the literal descriptions, it sounds like the woman|
                                        |suffered from abnormal uterine bleeding. This is entirely speculation, of course.|

     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Defiled…</char>in this context refers to something which was once or should be clean|
                                        |to the Jews but has transgressed into a state of uncleanness, temporarily (like in the case of unclean|
                                        |hands) or permanently. The Jews fit things into categories of clean and unclean, which leads to permissible|
                                        |and forbidden, and there were rules for restoring something which is unclean to clean. These rules should|
                                        |have been derived from the Law of Moses, but tradition was introduced alongside, and in cases supplanted,|
                                        |the Law of Moses, and this supplanting is what Jesus has issue with.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 16 omitted from some of the better manuscripts.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you’re allowed to eat any kind of food</char>…Lit: <char style="it">making clean all|
                                        |the food</char>. A subset of the Law of Moses is the kosher laws, which specifies certain food as “unclean”|
                                        |and therefore not permitted to be eaten. This single statement by Jesus obsoletes all the kosher laws,|
                                        |making it permissible for all food to be eaten from that time onward. This was a controversy in the first|
                                        |century church.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">take the children’s bread and toss it to the dogs</char>…Recall that in vv. 24,25 Jesus|
                                        |came to the house to get away from the crowds, because he needed a break. Then this Syro-Phoenician woman|
                                        |arrived and spoiled this respite. Jesus tells her that the Gentiles are a lower priority than the Jews:|
                                        |the children referred to in v.27 are the Israelites; the children’s bread is Jesus’s miraculous ministry;|
                                        |the children will “eat until they’re full,” then the Gentiles (the “dogs”) can take their turn. Her response|
                                        |is that the dogs eat at the same time as the children, not afterwards. Her faith got her the crumbs she|
                                        |was looking for.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He gave them orders…that they should not tell anyone…they went about spreading the word|
                                        |to others</char>…There are multiple instances where Jesus tells one or several people to keep quiet about|
                                        |the miracles he’s done, and they disobey. The result of their disobedience is that it limits the number|
                                        |of people Jesus can heal or otherwise set free; their disobedience causes others to continue in their|
                                        |suffering.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He continued speaking</char> <char style="it">to them</char>…This is an uninterrupted|

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he foams at the mouth and gnashes his teeth</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he foams and|
                                        |gnashes the teeth</char>. In the GT, two rhyming words are used for <char style="it">foams</char> <char|
                                        |style="it">and</char> <char style="it">gnashes</char>: <char style="it">aphridzay</char> <char style="it">kai|
                                        |tridzay </char>(ἀφρίζει καὶ τρίζει) <char style="w" strong="G00875">ἀφρίζει </char>), <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G02532">καὶ </char>), <char style="w" strong="G05149">τρίζει</char>). This rhyme or assonance|
                                        |presents a reasonable depiction of the truth (but not necessarily 100% accuracy) in an idiomatic expression.|
                                        |Similar to this, in English we say: wear and tear; hem and haw; whoop and holler; slip and slide.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he goes rigid,</char> <char style="it">tucking into a fetal position</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">he shrivels</char> <char style="it">(dries) up</char>. Same Gk. word used in Matt. 12:9 when|
                                        |describing the man with the shriveled hand. The boy became like a plant, a vegetable, or some other once-living|
                                        |object that shrivels up when it has dried out. When something like this dries out, it becomes stiff,|
                                        |shrinks in size, and tends to curl up upon itself in a ball of a sort.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by prayer…</char>Or: <char style="it">in prayer</char>. Some manuscripts say <char style="it">by|
                                        |prayer and fasting. </char>The word <char style="it">fasting </char>was added decades or centuries after|
                                        |Mark wrote his original manuscript. A similar insertion was made in 1 Cor. 7:5. There is no other NT|
                                        |reference that casting out evil spirits is contingent on fasting. Such false manuscript insertions (Mark|
                                        |9:29, 1 Cor. 7:5, Matt. 6:13, Mark 9:44) follow a pattern: years after the NT books were written, a few|
                                        |religious-minded folks read such passages and felt that God’s Word was not severe enough, or pious enough,|
                                        |or austere enough; or fearful of evil forces enough, and needed them to doctor it a bit.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">People are going to take the Man into custody, they’ll kill him, and, after he’s dead,|
                                        |he’ll be resurrected in three days</char>…Lit: <char style="it">The Son of Man is being handed over into|
                                        |the hands of men, and they will kill him, and, having died, after three days he will be resurrected</char>.|
                                        |By using the present tense here in <char style="it">is being handed over</char>, Jesus is summarizing|
                                        |a series or collection of events that will stretch out over days, and not just happen in minutes. |
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Indeed, if one were to do you a good turn because you are considered to be Christians</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">For he who were to give you all a cup of water to drink by name</char> [i.e. reputation],|
                                        |<char style="it">because you all are of Christ</char>, …Interpreting this statement literally makes no|
                                        |sense, because of the disagreement in plurality, specifically that one cup of water is being offered|
                                        |to “you all”: several people. This leads to the conclusion that the Gk. phrase for giving a cup of water|
                                        |is an idiomatic expression, the meaning of which is obvious. In addition, there is some disagreement|
                                        |in the manuscripts for the words <char style="it">by name</char> (or, as others assume, <char style="it">in|
                                        |name</char>). Some manuscripts have changed <char style="it">in name </char>to <char style="it">in his|
                                        |name.</char> The significance of this is to highlight the ambiguity of the meaning of this phrase. As|
                                        |such, a secondary translation of <char style="it">in name </char>was chosen, one found in the OT: <char|
                                        |style="it">in reputation</char>. This clarifies the ambiguity.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">where their parasitic worm infection will never go away and the fire won’t go out</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">Where their worm has no demise and the fire won’t go out</char>. Some manuscripts erroneously|
                                        |copied this over to vv. 44 and 46. Ref. note of v.41. In any case, <char style="it">their worm</char>|
                                        |here is a plural adjective modifying a singular noun; therefore, the “worm” referred to here is likely|
                                        |a bodily ailment, a parasitic infestation of worms, something like tapeworms or roundworms (ascariasis).|
                                        |In his short description of hell in v. 48, Jesus says that those in hell have worm infestations on the|
                                        |inside and are surrounded by fire on the outside. As the symptoms of a worm infestation include (but|
                                        |are not limited to) nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, a lack of appetite, weight loss, general weakness,|
                                        |Jesus was saying that those in hell experience these symptoms.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all</char> <char style="it">meats roasted</char> <char style="it">by a fire will be|
                                        |salted</char>…Or: <char style="it">everyone will be salted by a fire</char>. Verses 49 and 50 are ambiguous.|
                                        |For v. 49, some manuscripts read, <char style="it">for all sacrifices will be salted with salt. </char>Though|
                                        |this alternate reading has been rejected as spurious, the authors’ instincts for the true interpretation|
                                        |of these verses should not be. Therefore, the assumption is that v. 49 speaks of meats being seasoned|
                                        |with salt while being roasted, with salt added as a preservative. Verse 50 reads, <char style="it">as|
                                        |you have salt embedded in yourselves</char>. This becomes a metaphor; believers are compared to a hunk|
                                        |of meat which is roasted over a fire, having salt applied to them. After the roasting is complete, they|
                                        |have the salt in themselves, which means that they have the preservative effects of it. This affect is|
                                        |what allows them to live in peace with one another.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">if it’s legal…</char>The legality here is with respect to the Law of Moses|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Why do you call me ‘good’?…</char>Also ref. to note of Matt. 19:17. Why does Jesus take|
                                        |issue with being called good? He is good, of course. Two answers. First, he does not receive such pronouncements|
                                        |by any person, only by his Father. For the same reason, he rebuked demons when they said that he’s the|
                                        |Christ. It is the truth indeed, but such a truth he will only hear spoken by his Father. Second, he is|
                                        |still under the grand trial appointed to him by his Father, which will only be complete after his crucifixion.|
                                        |In his humility, he doesn’t consider himself to have earned the title of ‘good’ yet, and won’t until|
                                        |he’s raised from the dead. At that time, his Father will call him good, and not he call himself good.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">chiefs…</char>Lit: <char style="it">great ones</char>. Implies that they are charismatic,|
                                        |are valor-filled, and have despotic tendencies.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Bartimaeus…</char>Aramaic for <char style="it">son of Timaeus</char>; the Gk. equivalent|
                                        |is listed first but he goes by the Aramaic name. Mark is presenting Bartimaeus in a more familiar light,|
                                        |as an ordinary, common man—indeed, the lowest of the low.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">He threw off his cloak…</char>Some have asserted that Bartimaeus’s cloak was required|
                                        |of him being a beggar, and that he, casting it aside, believed he would be healed and therefore not need|
                                        |it anymore.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Teacher, I just want to see again…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Rabbi</char>—<char style="it">so|
                                        |that I would see again</char>. First, <char style="it">rabbi</char> here is one of the few places where|
                                        |Mark uses an Aramaic word. Second, only the second half of the sentence (<char style="it">so that I would|
                                        |see again</char>) is spoken; the first half is understood. Together, this shows Bartimaeus speaking in|
                                        |an everyday, ordinary, down-to-earth way, expected of one so low on the social hierarchy.|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Since figs weren’t in season…</char>Jesus found no figs on the fig tree when it wasn’t|
                                        |fig season and as a result cursed the tree. Why did Jesus expect to find figs on a tree when it wasn’t|
                                        |fig season? There are two times a year in which a fig tree bears figs. The main crop is in the late summer|
                                        |or fall and a secondary crop (called a <char style="it">breba</char>) is in the spring. The breba crop|
                                        |comes from shoots from the previous fall’s crop. Also, over the winter a fig tree will shed leaves. New|
                                        |leaves grow back in the spring, and this is what the phrase <char style="it">in leaf</char> refers to|
                                        |in v. 13. Also, the appearance of these new leaves coincides with the breba crop; hence, Jesus saw the|
                                        |new leaves and expected to see figs. When Mark said in v.13 that “figs weren’t in season,” he’s referring|
                                        |to the fall crop, not the breba crop.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those who were seated selling doves…</char>Ref. note of Matt. 12:21|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">robber’s hideout…</char>The Gk. word used here and in Matt. 21:13 is for <char style="it">robber|
                                        |</char>and not the one for <char style="it">thief. </char>A robber (not a thief) is described in Prov.|
                                        |1:8–19. He is one who lies in wait for his victim and will apply violence wantonly for even paltry gain.|
                                        |In modern times, you find thugs such as these in gangs or with drug traffickers.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Have the God-kind of faith…</char>Lit:<char style="it"> Be-having faith of-God</char>.|
                                        |A couple of relevant facts concerning the Gk. grammar in this short statement. First, the verb tense|
                                        |(present) of <char style="it">have </char>insinuates not just having once and being done with it but|
                                        |having continuously. Second, the lack of the definite article before <char style="it">faith </char>is|
                                        |conspicuous and was omitted intentionally by Mark. As a point of contrast, consider the example of Acts|
                                        |3:16, where the definite article is used before <char style="it">faith</char> (and this in a prepositional|
                                        |phrase, which often omits an expected definite article). In the case of v. 22 here, the omission of the|
                                        |definite article emphasizes the nature of the faith. Furthermore, the word <char style="it">God </char>is|
                                        |in the genitive case, but when a possessive is constructed in Gk. (an example in English would be, “This|
                                        |is Mary’s jar,” where <char style="it">Mary </char>appears in the possessive form), it normally consists|
                                        |of the definite article first, followed by the noun, followed by perhaps another article, then the genitive|
                                        |form of the noun doing the possessing. Since the initial definite article is missing, this disrupts the|
                                        |normal pattern of a Gk. possessive form, and signals a different meaning to the reader. Third, the lack|
                                        |of definite article before <char style="it">faith </char>emphasizes the nature of the faith.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Have the God-kind of faith…believe that you have received…</char>Some of the ancient|
                                        |manuscripts have doctored a few key words in vv.23,24. This is related to previous note. A minor change|
                                        |is in v. 23: some manuscripts have inserted the word <char style="it">to</char>, changing it from: <char|
                                        |style="it">have God’s faith, </char>to, <char style="it">if you have God’s faith</char>. A larger change|
                                        |is in v. 24: some manuscripts have changed the reading, <char style="it">believe that you have received,|
                                        |</char>to, <char style="it">believe that you are receiving.</char>|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">believe that you have received</char>…To quote Max &amp; Mary from <char style="it">A|
                                        |Grammatical Analysis of the Greek New Testament</char> with respect to the verb tense in the words <char|
                                        |style="it">have received</char>: “the future regarded with such certitude that it is assumed to have|
                                        |been realized already, but in the present is not regarded as having been complete yet.”|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 26’s ending, which reads, <char style="it">but if you don’t forgive, neither will your heavenly|
                                        |Father forgive your trespasses</char>, is omitted as spurious. Ref. note of Matt. 17:21.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">analogy…</char>Lit: <char style="it">parable</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a fence…</char>Lit: <char style="it">a hedge</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">They took him, kicked him out of the vineyard, and killed him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">They|
                                        |took him, killed him, and drove him outside of the vineyard</char>. The sequence of events was re-arranged|
                                        |to match the sequence from Matt 21:39. Also, same wording for <char style="it">kicked him out </char>as|
                                        |is used in Luke 13:28; ref. note there.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Herod supporters…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Herodians</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">since you’re not affected by people’s attitudes</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you don’t|
                                        |look to a face of men. </char>Ref. notes of Matt. 22:16.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">coin…</char>Lit: <char style="it">denarius</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who claim there is no life after death…</char>Lit: <char style="it">who say there isn’t|
                                        |a resurrection</char>. The word <char style="it">resurrection </char>here means <char style="it">life|
                                        |after death.</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Old Testament…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Moses wrote</char> or <char style="it">Moses</char>.|
                                        |The Law of Moses or the Torah, in other words.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you exist like the angels exist in the spiritual world</char>…Lit: <char style="it">but|
                                        |instead they are like the angels in the heavenlies</char>. Also of note: in this passage, the word <char|
                                        |style="it">you</char> is inserted instead of the actual word used in the GT, <char style="it">they</char>.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the designated teachers…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the Scribes</char>. Ref. note of|
                                        |Matt. 7:29.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the most important…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the first</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">entire life being…</char>Lit: <char style="it">soul</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you really hit the nail on the head…</char>Lit: <char style="it">at truth you spoke</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Messiah…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the Christ</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Until I decide to subdue your enemies and subjugate them to you</char>…Ref. note of|
                                        |Matt. 22:44|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">descendant…</char>Lit: <char style="it">son</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">quite a harsh sentence</char>…Lit: <char style="it">an exceedingly abundant sentence</char>.|
                                        |A figure of speech.|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">just what amount of money…</char>Consisting of coins of various amounts|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a couple of dollars…</char>lit: <char style="it">a two-lepta coin</char>. This is about|
                                        |the lowest denomination coin that was in circulation at the time.|
     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">everything she had to live on</char>…This phrase is a repetition of the phrase <char|
                                        |style="it">every cent that she had</char>. Such repetition is a figure of speech.|
     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">teacher…</char>Mark uses the Gk. word for <char style="it">teacher </char>here and not|
                                        |the Aramaic <char style="it">Rabbi </char>used several verses earlier (ref. Mark 9:5; 11:21). The shift|
                                        |in Mark’s choice of the word for <char style="it">teacher</char> here shows a subtle lack of affection|
                                        |and respect seeping out of the mouths of the Pharisees and Herodians (and later in v.19, the Sadducees),|
                                        |while they are trying to flatter Jesus. |
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">God’s not a God of the dead but of the living</char>…The point Jesus is making is that|
                                        |in the story of the burning bush, when God speaks to Moses, he refers to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who|
                                        |had died many years earlier, in the present tense, not in the past tense. If there was no life-after-death,|
                                        |he would have referred to them in the past tense; his referring to them in the present tense is proof|
                                        |that they still exist even though they’re dead.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">exceeds all burnt offerings and sacrifices</char>…The Law of Moses in the Old Testament|
                                        |commands Jews to offer to God burnt offerings and sacrifices. Both the commandments quoted in this passage|
                                        |and burnt offerings and sacrifices are required by the self-same Law of Moses.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">occupy the most prestigious seats</char>…Lit: <char style="it">first-seated</char> <char|
                                        |style="it">in the synagogues. </char>In the Israel of the Bible, seating at any event, even ones not|
                                        |steeped in formality, was done by the relative ranking of those seated; the greater status of the guest,|
                                        |the closer to the front or closer to the host or most prominent attendee was he placed. This explains|
                                        |Luke 14:8.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">gobble up widows’ homes…</char>Widows were the lowest ranked and most vulnerable in|
                                        |the socio-economic hierarchy of ancient Israel. There are numerous admonitions in the Old Testament to|
                                        |care for widows, to not take advantage of them, to look out for their well-being.|

     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Hope to God…</char>Ref. note of Matt. 24:20|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not a single living being</char>…Lit: <char style="it">no flesh</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on account of the Chosen Ones…</char>Lit: <char style="it">on account of the Chosen|
                                        |Ones who have been chosen</char>. The repetition in the phrase <char style="it">Chosen Ones who have|
                                        |been chosen </char>is a figure of speech.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Man…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the Son of Man</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">from one side of the planet to the other…</char>Ref. note of Matt. 24:31|

                                        |are his business ventures…warehouses, glass-making, tanneries, potteries, wineries…perhaps herds, fields,|
                                        |silos.|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">applies to you as well…</char>Lit: <char style="it">what I’m telling you all, I’m saying|
                                        |to everyone</char>|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I am the one-and-only one…</char>Lit: <char style="it">I am</char>. Same words Jesus|
                                        |spoke in John 8:58, which in turn is a repetition of Exod. 3:14. Saying “I am” implies saying “I am the|
                                        |eternal God incarnate.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The local council</char>…In this context, though it could refer to the national council|
                                        |(which was like a Supreme Court), the Sanhedrin, which in Matthew is called the <char style="it">Council|
                                        |of the Elders</char>, but more likely refers to a local tribunal of elders.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have the one who reads this out loud to the congregation get up to speed on this ahead|
                                        |of time</char>…Ref. note of Matt. 24:15|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t have whoever’s on the porch go down, go in, and fetch anything out of the house…</char>Ref.|
                                        |note of Matt. 24:17|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Oh, how terrible it’ll be for women at that time who are pregnant or have infants!</char>…Ref.|
                                        |note of Matt. 24:19|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">keep watch…stay alert…stay focused…</char>Lit: <char style="it">keep watch</char>. The|
                                        |GT uses the same word for <char style="it">keep watch </char>at the end of v.34 (<char style="it">keep|
                                        |watch</char>), at the beginning of v. 35 (<char style="it">stay alert</char>), and at the end of v. 37|
                                        |(<char style="it">stay focused</char>). |
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">whether at daybreak…</char>The times listed in v.35 (sunset, middle of the night, just|
                                        |before daybreak, daybreak) are all times when it is dark or nearly dark and are listed in the order of|
                                        |the Jewish day. In other words, since the Jewish day starts at sunset, the hours of darkness or near|
                                        |darkness progress from sunset to the middle of the night, just before daybreak, and finally to daybreak.|
                                        |Also, in the GT, Mark inserts the word <char style="it">whether </char>before each time…<char style="it">whether|
                                        |at sunset, whether in the middle of the night, whether just before daybreak, whether daybreak</char>.|
                                        |His point is to cover the entire night, from beginning to end, starting when it begins to get dark and|
                                        |ending when it’s still a bit dark in the morning.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">But the point that I’m making in this story applies to you all as well</char>…In this|
                                        |parable, the servants are all assigned responsibilities, and their responsibilities by default include|
                                        |keeping watch during the day, as they’ll be up and about minding shop during daylight hours, but do not|
                                        |included keeping watch at night. The job of keeping the night watch is assigned solely to the doorman.|
                                        |If the estate owner were to come in the middle of the night and catch everyone asleep, it will be the|
                                        |doorman’s fault and not the servants’, since the servants are expected to sleep at night. The doorman|
                                        |is the lowest ranking servant on the estate (the Gk. word for <char style="it">doorman </char>is alternatively|
                                        |translated <char style="it">porter</char> or <char style="it">janitor</char>); the servants are assigned|
                                        |more important duties. The doorman’s temptation is to neglect his night watch duties, as the servants,|
                                        |those senior to him, will sleep through the night and therefore not keep tabs on him. The admonition|
                                        |Jesus makes is for the doorman (and us by extension) to stay alert every night, throughout the entire|
                                        |night, as the estate owner could come at any time.|

     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">let this ordeal pass me by…</char>Lit: <char style="it">bear this cup past and away|
                                        |from me</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">evermore stay focused in prayer…</char>Lit: <char style="it">watch and pray</char>.|
                                        |Wording it this way instead of <char style="it">pray watchfully </char>is a figure of speech. And also,|
                                        |the word <char style="it">watch</char> in this context means <char style="it">focus</char>. And also,|
                                        |the word <char style="it">evermore </char>amplifies the verb tense in <char style="it">watch and pray.</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reach the point where trials can break you…</char>Lit: <char style="it">so that you|
                                        |won’t come into temptation</char>. <char style="it">Temptation</char> here is testing to the breaking|
                                        |point, in addition to its commonly-understood meaning.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">is gung-ho…</char>Also: <char style="it">all for it</char>; <char style="it">desires|
                                        |it passionately</char>|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">human nature…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the flesh</char>. Impl. the carnal nature|
                                        |present in every person.|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">here we go…</char>Lit: <char style="it">behold</char>|
     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">councilmen…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the elders</char>. Impl. the Sanhedrin.|
     u                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Teacher…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Rabbi</char>. Using the affectionate form (ref.|
                                        |Mark 10:51) for the word <char style="it">teacher</char>, this could more accurately be rendered, <char|
                                        |style="it">beloved teacher.</char>|
     v                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to find someone to testify under oath…</char>Ref. note of Matt 26:59|
     w                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I am the one-and-only one…</char>Lit: <char style="it">I am. </char>Ref. Mark 13:5|
     x                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">In his role as a powerful right-hand man</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Sitting at the|
                                        |right-hand of power</char>|
     y                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">became unglued and in a rage starting breaking things</char>…Lit: <char style="it">So|
                                        |the high priest tore his cloak</char>. Some liberties taken; Ref. note of Matt. 26:65.|
     y                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">cracked…</char>Lit: <char style="it">break</char>; <char style="it">shatter</char>;|
                                        |<char style="it">crush</char>. What Mark is conveying is the tearing or breaking of an expensive seal,|
                                        |elaborate packaging, or a one-time breaking of some sort of container. Just as it is today, expensive|
                                        |items back then came with elaborate seals, not just simple lids. The manufacturer of an expensive item|
                                        |will purposely intend the breaking open of such a container to become a pleasing ritual and a means of|
                                        |fueling the hype and anticipation of discovering its contents.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one who raises his glass to offer a toast</char>…Lit: <char style="it">dips in the dish|
                                        |with me</char>. Some liberties taken; ref. note of Matt. 26:23.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">took a loaf of bread, gave thanks, broke it</char>…Breaking of bread was a ritual; ref.|
                                        |note of Matt. 14:19.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">This is my blood of the covenant</char>…Some of the older manuscripts have an alternate|
                                        |reading, <char style="it">this is my blood which is of the covenant</char>, while others read, <char|
                                        |style="it">this is my blood of the new covenant</char>. The evidence for the accepted reading is sufficient|
                                        |to accept what’s rendered here as genuine. It remains for us to accept what Jesus said at face value.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">and again he found them sleeping; they didn’t know what they would say in response to|
                                        |him since their eyelids were sagging</char>…Lit: <char style="it">And again he found them sleeping, since|
                                        |their eyelids were sagging, and they didn’t know how they might reply to him</char>. They were sleeping|
                                        |because they didn’t know how to reply to Jesus?—An example of Mark’s clumsy writing.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(V.48) <char style="it">said to the party</char>…(v.50) <char style="it">everyone standing there</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">said to them</char> (v.48); <char style="it">all of them</char> (v.50). It’s known by|
                                        |the context what the antecedent of <char style="it">them </char>is in both cases, but the potential for|
                                        |ambiguity would otherwise exist. Another example of Mark’s clumsy writing.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A certain young man…</char>Some assert that the “certain young man” referred to in v.51|
                                        |is none other than Mark himself. At a minimum, Mark’s book is worded in such a way that the reader would|
                                        |understand who he was talking about. Patching together NT verses here and there and also church tradition,|
                                        |Mark was the son of Mary, who owned the upper room where the Last Supper was held. Mark wasn’t one of|
                                        |Jesus’s disciples, either because he was too young to be so, didn’t know him until the Passover week,|
                                        |or both; but he followed Jesus and the Twelve Disciples after they left the upper room to Gethsemane.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">but he shed the garment they grabbed and ran away naked…</char>From the sounds of it,|
                                        |when those in the party tried to grab ahold of the young man, they could just barely get ahold of him.|
                                        |They weren’t able to arms, legs, neck, or grab him around his waist; all they could do is get a hand|
                                        |on his linen garment. He squirmed, the loin cloth came off, and he continued to bolt. This probably would’ve|
                                        |taken place in just a few seconds.|
     I                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a rooster crowed </char>(v.68)…<char style="it">a rooster crowed</char> <char style="it">a|
                                        |second time</char> (v.72)…These words are missing from a few of the most reliable manuscripts. It’s possible|
                                        |that others added what Mark in his clumsiness neglected. |
     J                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">it hit him like a ton of bricks…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Having thrown upon, he|
                                        |started crying</char>. The single Gk. word <char style="it">epiballō </char>(ἐπιβάλλω /Strong’s 1911).|
                                        |Apparently an idiom of some sort; it’s not entirely certain what the exact meaning of this is when used|
                                        |as an idiom. Some translators render it, <char style="it">He broke down and cried</char>.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the high priests, along with all the councilmen and the designated teachers</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">the high priests with the elders, the scribes, and the entire Sanhedrin</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Whatever you say…</char>Lit:<char style="it"> You say</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the governor’s security guards…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the praetorian</char>. Similar|
                                        |to the Roman Praetorian Guard but applied to the governor’s (Pilate’s) palace.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">placed on him…</char>Lit: <char style="it">placed around him</char>. The use of the|
                                        |word <char style="it">around </char>instead of <char style="it">on, </char>and the fact that the word|
                                        |for <char style="it">crown </char>here is something similar to a Roman laurel wreath indicates that the|
                                        |crown indeed was just like we see in the pictures and movies about Jesus.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Pleased to meet you, King of the Jews…</char>Lit: <char style="it">Joy, King of the|
                                        |Jews</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they led him away to be crucified…</char>Lit: <char style="it">they led him out in order|
                                        |that they might crucify him</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to carry…</char>Lit: <char style="it">to take up</char>. The Gk. word rendered <char|
                                        |style="it">carry</char> in v.21 is the same word used in Matt. 16:24 (<char style="it">to take up</char>).|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">up on top of…</char>Or: <char style="it">to the exact location of</char>; <char style="it">to</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rolling dice…</char>Some liberty taken; they cast lots instead of rolling dice.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Now it was mid-morning when they performed the crucifixion on him</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">Now it was the third hour and they crucified him</char>. The two thoughts (#1: <char style="it">it|
                                        |was the third hour</char>; #2: <char style="it">they crucified him</char>) separated by the word <char|
                                        |style="it">and </char>rather than combining them is a figure of speech.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one to the left of him and one to the right of him</char>…Also: <char style="it">one|
                                        |at his left hand and one at his right hand</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 28 which reads, <char style="it">And the Scripture which says, “And he was counted with lawless|
                                        |men,”</char> is spurious and therefore omitted.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">designated teachers…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the Scribes</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">let out a great cry and passed away</char>…Lit: <char style="it">he exhaled</char>,|
                                        |or, <char style="it">his spirit went out of him</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">temple curtain…</char>Ref. note of Matt. 27:52|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a son…</char>The rendering <char style="it">a son</char> should not insinuate that the|
                                        |Son of God is one of many sons of God. The GT does not say that.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">among whom were…</char>The GT includes a leading <char style="it">and</char> to the|
                                        |list of women, and this <char style="it">and, </char>though omitted in the rendering, seems to imply|
                                        |that all the women who were watching from a distance are listed in vv.40,41; that there were no other|
                                        |women present.|
     r                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who also was himself a true believer…</char>Lit: <char style="it">who also was personally|
                                        |receiving to himself the kingdom of God</char>|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">if it had been a while since he died</char>…some of the older manuscripts instead read,|
                                        |<char style="it">if he had died</char>.|
     s                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">along with the revolutionaries…during the insurrection…</char>As v.8 is worded in the|
                                        |GT, <char style="it">the revolutionaries</char> and <char style="it">the insurrection</char> refer to|
                                        |a specific group of insurgents and a specific rebellion, lost to history perhaps, but known to Mark’s|
                                        |readers.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a robe a nobleman would wear</char>…The Gk. word <char style="it">prophyra </char><char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G04209">πορφύρα</char>)<char style="it">. </char>It means two things: it means <char|
                                        |style="it">purple</char> and it also refers to the Murex snail from which purple dye is extracted. In|
                                        |modern times, dyes are synthesized at a low cost from chemical compounds, and so there is an abundance|
                                        |of cheap, multi-colored clothing. In ancient times only by harvesting Murex snails from the ocean could|
                                        |one produce a purple dye, so the clothing made from this dye was expensive. Since only the wealthy nobles|
                                        |could afford it, purple coloring was associated with nobility.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spiced wine…</char>Lit: <char style="it">myrrh-mixed wine</char>. Also ref. Matt. 27:34,|
                                        |Ps. 69:21. Roman soldiers normally drank a wine which was at least partly vinegar; the sour taste helped|
                                        |quench one’s thirst, something like putting a slice of lemon in a glass of iced tea. Obviously, however,|
                                        |too much vinegar would make the drink unpalatable, and apparently they mixed myrrh to limit the extent|
                                        |to which the wine degraded into vinegar, as it would naturally do so when exposed to the air. But the|
                                        |myrrh was also slightly narcotic, and Jesus apparently refuses it so that the wine won’t ameliorate his|
                                        |suffering.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mid-morning…noon…late afternoon…Mid-morning</char> in the GT is the third hour. The|
                                        |Jewish regular hours of prayer and of sacrifices instituted the third, sixth, and ninth hours of the|
                                        |day. Out of this, the third, sixth, and ninth hours became the way of specifying approximate points during|
                                        |the day (ref. Matt. 20:1–17), and they correspond to what we call mid-morning, noon, middle of the afternoon,|
                                        |and late afternoon. In spite of the fact that they are numerical values in a twelve hour day, they are|
                                        |not as exact as their nominal values suggest.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a</char> <char style="it">pre-Sabbath preparatory day</char>…The Sabbath here could|
                                        |be either a Saturday or a feast day. Naturally, one would want to remove dead bodies immediately; furthermore,|
                                        |dead bodies should not remain on the Sabbath. Work was forbidden on the Sabbath, not to mention the aversion|
                                        |and restrictions the Jews had concerning dead bodies.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">just after the Sabbath restrictions came to a close</char>…The Jewish day ended at sundown,|
                                        |so the Sabbath ended at sundown. Once the Sabbath was over, the women could conduct business.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Very early on Sunday morning…</char>Lit: <char style="it">very early in the first of|
                                        |the Sabbaths </char>(v.2). Ref. Matt. 28:1 for “Sabbaths” use in plural. The “first of the Sabbaths”|
                                        |is a Sunday; also ref. John 2:1; Acts 20:7 Related to this, v.9 reads lit.: <char style="it">now having|
                                        |been resurrected early on the first of the Sabbath</char>…|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">refusal to believe</char>…<char style="it">refused to believe</char>…Lit: <char style="it">unbelief</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the inhabited world…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the world. </char>Refers to the people|
                                        |who live on the earth, rather than the earth per se.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">preach a complete round</char>…This is the word <char style="it">preach </char>in the|
                                        |aorist tense, not the expected present tense. The use of aorist over present tense views the proclamation|
                                        |of the gospel as a one-time event, rather than a never-ending series of proclamations. The one-time preaching|
                                        |of the gospel views takes all the individual proclamations and views them as a single set. In other words,|
                                        |make sure everyone gets to hear it at least once.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Good News…</char>Lit: <char style="it">the Gospel</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">anything that has two legs</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all of creation</char>. This|
                                        |is a figure of speech, as Jesus isn’t commanding the disciples to preach to dogs or mountains or such.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">kept from destruction…</char>Lit: <char style="it">saved</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">accompany…</char>Lit: <char style="it">follow alongside</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">by my authority…</char>Lit: <char style="it">in my name. </char>Ref. note of Acts 4:7.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they will remove serpents, taking them out of the way</char>…Also: <char style="it">they|
                                        |will lift up serpents</char>. Some manuscripts read, <char style="it">they will lift up serpents with|
                                        |their hands</char>, appending the words <char style="it">with their hands.</char> The word used for <char|
                                        |style="it">lift up</char> here is translated various ways depending on context.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assumed his position as God’s chief executive</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sat at the|
                                        |right hand of God</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">tell his disciples and Peter</char>…If there’s any doubt that Mark was close to Peter,|
                                        |remarks such as these should lay that doubt to rest. In multiple places Mark points Peter out, mentioning|
                                        |what he’s doing. Furthermore, he often uses the name <char style="it">Peter</char>, the one given to|
                                        |him by Jesus,<char style="it"> </char>instead of ones that others called him, <char style="it">Simon</char>|
                                        |or <char style="it">Cephas</char>.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Those who deny that vv. 9–20 are genuine build their argument not on the manuscript evidence (which is|
                                        |certainly not in their favor) but instead on “internal” evidence, i.e. whether they think these verses|
                                        |fit Mark’s style of writing and his use of vocabulary. Their claims:|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(a) <char style="it">Mary Magdalene, whom he had cast out seven demons</char> (v.9). They claim that|
                                        |the writer is introducing Mary Magdalene here, noting the demons cast out of her, but in fact she had|
                                        |been referred to just a few times in the preceding verses and chapters.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(b) Some words occur in this passage that Mark doesn’t use anywhere else|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(c) The writing is simply not Mark’s style|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Let us look at these claims in detail.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |First, Mark mentions that Mary Magdalene had had seven demons cast out of her. Any forger would know|
                                        |that Mary Magdalene was brought up in v.1 and would’ve written accordingly. But the extra statement of|
                                        |her having demons cast out is not an introduction but a reminder of the grace she had received, resulting|
                                        |in a tender heart which caused her to be the first to believe when the others wouldn’t. To emphasize|
                                        |this, Mark, when he said <char style="it">had cast out</char>, chose to use the Gk. perfect tense over|
                                        |the aorist for emphasis. In support of this, v.10 begins with the words <char style="it">that lady</char>,|
                                        |which invites the reader to detach himself and ponder her history. The other women weren’t address in|
                                        |that fashion.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Second, there are a few words which Mark uses in this passage that don’t appear elsewhere in his book|
                                        |(never mind the fact that every chapter of Mark has unique words used in its chapter which Mark uses|
                                        |nowhere else). Let us look at these words:|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(i) <char style="it">Accompany</char> (v.17). This is a more specific word that pre-pends the word <char|
                                        |style="it">with </char>to <char style="it">follow. </char>Certainly Mark knew the meaning of this word.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(ii) <char style="it">Serpent</char> (v.18). A common word.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(iii) <char style="it">Hurt</char> (v.18). Ranks 2808<char style="sup">th</char> out of 5394, where 1|
                                        |is most common and 5394 is least. This word is uncommon.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(iv) <char style="it">Poison</char> (v.18). Derived from a very common root.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(v) The phrase <char style="it">so then</char> (v. 19). Two extremely common words used as a phrase.|
                                        |Mark certainly knew the meaning of the phrase, but didn’t use it anywhere else.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(vi) <char style="it">Working alongside</char> (v.20). This is the verb form of the commonly-used noun|
                                        |<char style="it">fellow-worker.</char>|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |(vii) <char style="it">Confirm</char> (v.20). Appears as 2803<char style="sup">rd</char> out of 5394.|
                                        |This word is uncommon and is not derived from a commonly used root.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |We can strike serpent, hurt, and poison from the list, since there are no alternatives for these words;|
                                        |Mark would’ve asked the scribe who was doing the actual writing to supply these words had he not known|
                                        |them and when he had need of them. This leaves four words, three of which are common, and Mark certainly|
                                        |knew, but he hadn’t used before. The list of uncommon words is whittled down to the single word <char|
                                        |style="it">confirm.</char>|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |As far as the style is concerned—and this is quite open-ended—true, Mark shifts his preference in verb|
                                        |tenses around, but this passage has little story-telling narrative. Another thing to note are the figures|
                                        |of speech used in vv.15,16. Would a forgerer risk using a figure or speech? Would a forgerer dwell on|
                                        |the disciples not believing when they should have (vv.13,14). While all these things with style are debatable,|
                                        |they are not definitive in determining whether the long ending of vv.9–20 is spurious or not.|

******************  LUKE   **************
