     t                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ten and eight years</char>…This is the literal rendering of the GT. In v. 18, Luke writes|
                                        |<char style="it">eighteen </char>as single word, then when quoting Jesus here in v. 16 he writes <char|
                                        |style="it">ten and eight </char>instead of the shorter <char style="it">eighteen. </char>The longer form|
                                        |is a word-for-word translation from the Aramaic which Jesus spoke into Gk., and is preceded by the word|
                                        |<char style="it">behold </char>(rendered <char style="it">get this</char>). Together, the words <char|
                                        |style="it">behold </char>and <char style="it">ten and eight </char>emphasize how long she had been afflicted.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you need to get your head straightened out</char>…Lit: <char style="it">whence are you?</char>|
                                        |The phrase <char style="it">whence are you </char>is an expression, the keyword being <char style="it">whence|
                                        |</char>(<char style="it">pothen</char>, πόθεν/Strong’s 4159). This expression also appears in John 7:27–28|
                                        |(three times); John 8:14 (somewhat); John 9:29–30; John 19:9. The expression roughly corresponds to the|
                                        |English, <char style="it">where are you coming from? </char>Alternately, it may mean, <char style="it">what|
                                        |are you all about?</char>; w<char style="it">hat’s your driving motivation?; what makes you tick?; what’s|
                                        |your raison d’être?; I don’t know if you’re on the level; you’re a wacko. </char>On another note, this|
                                        |phrase is repeated in v. 27. The principle manuscripts differ in the reading. The accepted reading is|
                                        |lit. <char style="it">I don’t know you, whence you are</char>; but other principal manuscripts read <char|
                                        |style="it">I don’t know whence you are. </char>The latter is a shortened version of a well-known expression,|
                                        |readily understood and registered as such by the hearer because of the conspicuousness of the word <char|
                                        |style="it">whence.</char>|

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">So now, the salt source works well</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Therefore, the salt|
                                        |works well </char>[<char style="it">or is good</char>]. It’s uncertain how this should be rendered or|
                                        |what this is referring to (also, see Mark 9:49,50). The interpolation <char style="it">source </char>is|
                                        |a best-guess. Some problems with this passage of vv. 34,35 is this. First, salt doesn’t just become insipid|
                                        |(loses its saltiness). Salt is a simple compound that doesn’t spoil like a biomass. Second, in v. 35,|
                                        |the suggestion is to not put the salt in the ground or the compost pile (lit: <char style="it">manure|
                                        |pile</char>). Even if salt did lose its potency, it’s still salt, and as salt it will poison any ground|
                                        |or compost it’s applied to. One will never put actual salt in the ground or in a compost pile. There|
                                        |must be more to the story here.|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the designated teachers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Scribes</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">heartily welcomes</char>…Lit: <char style="it">receives</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’m so glad and excited because I found my missing sheep. High-fives!</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">Rejoice with me, because I found my missing sheep</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A certain man had two sons, and this is what he experienced with them</char>…The interpolation|
                                        |<char style="it">and this is what he experience with them </char>is insinuated by the verb tense of the|
                                        |word <char style="it">had </char>(which should actually be <char style="it">was having </char>instead)|
                                        |in <char style="it">a certain man had.</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">more than enough food to eat</char>…Lit: <char style="it">abound of loaves of bread</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">threw his arms around his neck</char>…Lit<char style="it">: fell upon his neck</char>.|
                                        |As the words <char style="it">fell upon</char> in the Bible usually refer to one person or party attacking|
                                        |another, the fervency in which the father hugged him around the neck is both a metaphor to attacking|
                                        |someone and also an hyperbole.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">you always have been and always will be with me</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you are|
                                        |with me always</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">$100 bills</char>…Lit: <char style="it">drachma</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 17:24 for|
                                        |conversion of drachmas to dollars.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the presence of the angels</char>…Lit: <char style="it">before the angels of God</char>.|
                                        |The angels of God in this context are the angels who surround God; the joy they are having is a metonymy|
                                        |for God’s joy, which extends to all heavenly beings surrounding Him.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I have sinned against God and eversomuch against you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I|
                                        |have sinned unto the heaven and before you</char>. The Jews say <char style="it">heaven</char> as a metonymy|
                                        |in place of God, to avoid speaking His name. His sin was “unto God” but it was before his father. In|
                                        |the Bible, before a person means that it is something that that person puts their focus and full attention|
                                        |on, and implies that that person is ever cognizant of.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Premier Robe</char>…<char style="it">ring for his finger</char>…Like Joseph’s robe of|
                                        |many colors, this Premier Robe (lit: <char style="it">First Robe</char>) here is a visible indication|
                                        |of ranking and status. It shows that the son is reinstated to a position of authority in the family,|
                                        |having authority over the workers who report to the father. The ring is likely a signet ring, one used|
                                        |to affix the family seal on legal documents, giving him authority to transact business in the father’s|
                                        |name, similar to a credit card or even power of attorney.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">everything I own is yours</char>…This remark indicates that the older son, the faithful|
                                        |one, had the right to do anything he wanted with his father’s possessions, as his father considered that|
                                        |the elder son had joint ownership of them. Notice the word <char style="it">them </char>is used in v.|
                                        |12 and not the word <char style="it">him</char>: <char style="it">he distributed the estate among them</char>.|
                                        |This is further evidence that the father had given the faithful son full control over the entire estate.|
                                        |The older son’s problem is that he was waiting for the father to throw him a party; he could’ve thrown|
                                        |one himself.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">account manager</char>…Lit: <char style="it">steward</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Explain your handling of the accounts</char>…Or (possibly): <char style="it">Give me|
                                        |your accounting ledger</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’m too proud</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I’m ashamed</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">cherish</char>…Lit: <char style="it">love </char>[<char style="it">agapaō </char><char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G00025">ἀγαπάω</char>)]|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">held in high regard and flaunted</char>…Lit: <char style="it">exalted</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">detestable</char>…Also <char style="it">abominable</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The Old Testament</char>…Lit: <char style="it">The Law and the Prophets</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">for the known universe to come to an end</char>…Lit: <char style="it">for the sky and|
                                        |the earth to pass by</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a single stroke of the pen which distinguishes one letter from another in the Bible|
                                        |to be invalidated</char>…Lit: <char style="it">one serif in the Law to fall</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Everyone who gets divorced and then remarries commits adultery</char>…Lit: <char style="it">everyone|
                                        |who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery, and every woman divorcee who remarries commits|
                                        |adultery</char>. The GT is worded this way because only the husband had the legal right to obtain a divorce,|
                                        |not the wife.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">was dressed in the best clothing like all the other rich are</char>…Lit: <char style="it">was|
                                        |clothed in purple and fine linen</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">living high off the hog</char>…Also: <char style="it">sumptuously</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Bible</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Moses and the Prophets</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">straighten up</char>…Lit: <char style="it">repent</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">100 containers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">100 baths</char>. A <char style="it">bath</char>|
                                        |is an ancient Israeli unit of measurement equivalent to 5.8 gallons (21.9 liters). In all probability,|
                                        |olive oil containers like this consisted of large jars, pots, etc. of pottery that could hold a single|
                                        |bath. In today’s retail price for olive oil, one bath of olive oil would sell for around $240, setting|
                                        |the total value of all 100 baths at $23,000.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">100 barrels</char>…Lit: <char style="it">100 measures</char>. One <char style="it">measure</char>|
                                        |was ten times larger than a bath, making a measure equal to 58 gallons (220 liters). For perspective,|
                                        |a barrel of crude oil is 42 gallons; a measure is 6 times larger than a bushel. In today’s prices, 100|
                                        |baths (600 bushels) of wheat is valued around $3,000. Now, wheat production nowadays has been automated|
                                        |to a greater extent, relatively speaking, than other commodities, so the effective dollar equivalent|
                                        |value for us would exceed $3,000.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those who go with the flow in this awful world-system are shrewder than those who follow|
                                        |the light when it comes to dealing with their own kind</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the sons of this|
                                        |age are more sensible </char>[or:<char style="it"> prudent; wise</char>]<char style="it"> over the sons|
                                        |of light unto their own generation</char>. A clearer meaning of the word <char style="it">age</char>|
                                        |as used in this verse can be found in Eph. 2:2.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Almighty Dollar used for wrong-doing</char>…Lit<char style="it">: the mammon of|
                                        |wrong-doing</char>. The Aramaic word <char style="it">mammon</char> used in the NT carries with it negative|
                                        |connotations. The word <char style="it">wrong-doing</char> is a repetition of the “for the wrong-doing”|
                                        |(v. 8), as what Jesus says in v. 9 is a reference to that parable.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they just might take you into the condos </char>[<char style="it">liberties taken; </char>lit:<char|
                                        |style="it"> tents or tabernacles</char>]<char style="it"> which are eternal</char>…The wording of this|
                                        |sentence, along with the grammatical forms of these words, is a repetition of “they just might take me|
                                        |into their houses” ( v. 4), except <char style="it">tents</char> is substituted for <char style="it">houses</char>.|
                                        |Also, the word <char style="it">tents</char> is a Semitic figure of speech used in the OT (like in 1|
                                        |Kings 12:16) which uses words from the bygone-days of Israel that were bygone in Jesus’s time, as it|
                                        |hearkens back to the days before they were a nation but were nomads, like in the time of Abraham, still|
                                        |living in tents.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">custodian</char>…Lit: <char style="it">domestic servant</char>. Not the usual words|
                                        |for servant, but a word having the same root as <char style="it">account manager</char> (<char style="it">steward</char>)|
                                        |as used in this passage. Both <char style="it">domestic servant</char> and <char style="it">steward</char>|
                                        |take care of someone else’s possessions. The words suggest that the domestic servant is in training or|
                                        |aspires to become a steward. As there is linking of the words for steward and domestic servant, v. 13|
                                        |is a continuation of the parable of the steward.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">is confronted with agonizing choices</char>…Lit: <char style="it">suffers violence</char>.|
                                        |The word for <char style="it">suffers violence</char> is an idiom; though the exact meaning is not entirely|
                                        |certain, it seems to mean that a person has to make difficult decisions to the point of undergoing hardships,|
                                        |of acting decisively, of exercising his willpower to the uttermost extent, and of challenging his most|
                                        |fundamental and sacred beliefs. Ref. Matt. 11:12.|
     H                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to be in tight with Abraham, forever close to him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the|
                                        |bosom of Abraham</char>. To a person to “be in the bosom of so-and-so” is for that person’s head to be|
                                        |in so-and-so’s lap while he’s reclined at the dinner table. Lazarus is reclined in such a way that his|
                                        |head is in Abraham’s lap, as John was in Jesus’s in John 13:23. “Abraham’s bosom” is a metaphor of close|
                                        |friendship, as the one who lies for a meal and places his head in another’s bosom is best of friends.|
     I                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the world-to-come</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Hades</char>. Hades is the Greek god|
                                        |of mythology who’s god of the underworld. It is also a synecdoche for the underworld itself, the place|
                                        |where people go after they die. The writers of the NT used the word <char style="it">Hades </char>in|
                                        |an abstract manner; in other words, they used it to refer to the place people go when they die. However,|
                                        |just because the NT uses the word Hades doesn’t mean that it concurs with all of what the Greeks thought|
                                        |of the underworld. It is simply the place where the dead go. As can be seen in this story, it consists|
                                        |of the place where both the good and the bad go after they die.|
     J                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">send Lazarus</char>…There is evidence that Lazarus was at one time the rich man’s servant:|
                                        |first, because the rich man recognized Lazarus at a distance; second, because he knew his name; third,|
                                        |the fact that Lazarus was stationed at his front gate, not far from where he had once lived; fourth,|
                                        |that the rich man is asking for service from Lazarus, something he was accustomed to doing while alive.|
                                        |As it appears, when Lazarus became too old or too frail to perform his duties, the rich man tossed him|
                                        |out on the street, where he had to beg for the remainder of his life. The rich man’s wealth and lavish|
                                        |lifestyle wasn’t directly responsible for his punishment in the afterlife, but the wealth and deceitful|
                                        |lifestyle fueled a disdain for his fellow man, and that ultimately is what landed him in hell. There|
                                        |are commandments in the Old Testament for showing kindness to the less-fortunate; the rich man disobeyed|
                                        |these.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">various means of getting tripped up or falling into sin</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stumbling|
                                        |blocks</char>. Ref. Matt. 18:6.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">multiple times in one day, to the point where you’ve had enough, and each time</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">seven times in one day, and seven times</char>. In the Bible, the number seven is the|
                                        |number of completion. |
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">missionaries</char>…Lit: <char style="it">apostles</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have a seat</char>…Lit: <char style="it">recline</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">taking my meal</char>…Lit: <char style="it">eating and drinking</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not effective enough as servants</char>…Lit: <char style="it">unprofitable servants</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">purged</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cleansed</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">because you sit down and go over everything with a fine-toothed comb</char>…Also: <char|
                                        |style="it">with close inspection. </char>This is what some nowadays are guilty of.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Look right here and look over there</char>…Lit: <char style="it">behold here or there</char>.|
                                        |Possibly rendered, “Look—it’s right here,” or, “It’s over there.”|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Man</char>…Lit<char style="it">: the Son of Man</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t go on a wild goose chase</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Neither depart nor pursue</char>.|
                                        |The wording of the GT suggests that this is an expression.|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">were living it up non-stop</char>…Lit: <char style="it">were eating and eating, drinking|
                                        |and drinking</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">flaming sulfur</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fire and brimstone</char>. An expression|
                                        |used throughout the Bible. It’s a figure of speech where one should remove the word <char style="it">and|
                                        |</char>between <char style="it">fire and brimstone.</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">lying on a single bed</char>…Or possibly: <char style="it">two reclined </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">for dinner</char>]<char style="it"> on a single couch</char>.|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Go show yourselves to the priests</char>…Ref. note of Matt. 8:4; see also Luke 5:14|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">who’s of another nationality</char>…Ref. notes of Matt. 15:26, Mark 7:27|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Man will be the same way</char>…The principle manuscripts are split evenly on this,|
                                        |with the alternate reading, <char style="it">the Man will be the same way when his day arrives </char>[<char|
                                        |style="it">lit: in his day</char>]. The added phrase or something to that effect was insinuated by Luke,|
                                        |so the interpolation is correct, though it’s doubtful that these words appeared in the autograph.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">out on the back deck</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon the housetop</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken. Ancient Israeli houses had flat roofs, and they used their roofs like we use porches and decks.|
                                        |Likewise, this explains Prov. 25:24.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on that dreadful night</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with this night</char>. Verse 31|
                                        |starts out with Jesus saying <char style="it">on that day</char>, but now he’s talking about “that night”|
                                        |instead of “that day.” He’s actually speaking of the same day, but he switches to saying night to signal|
                                        |that something dreadful is to take place.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 36 missing from the better manuscripts|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">they said</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they say</char>. In the NT, narrative commonly|
                                        |switches to the present tense for effect, when the past tense is the true meaning. This is a figure of|
                                        |speech which conveys to the reader how tightly the sequential actions in a narrative are coupled; that|
                                        |things are unfolding in real-time; the continuity of a conversation. The present tense puts the reader|
                                        |in the midst of the conversation as it’s unfolding, rather than looking at a stale description of how|
                                        |it turned out.|

     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">toddlers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">babies</char>. When Luke states in v. 16 that|
                                        |he <char style="it">called them over</char>, the antecedent of <char style="it">them </char>is the word|
                                        |<char style="it">babies </char>in v. 15, and this word <char style="it">babies </char>normally refers|
                                        |to newborns, but it’s inferred that Luke is referring to toddlers and not newborns, since babies are|
                                        |too young to respond to a person beckoning them to come. However, since the word <char style="it">babies|
                                        |</char>is used, by our classification of minors from birth to adulthood, this would mean very young children|
                                        |(toddlers) rather than just children generically, since the word children has connotations of a minor|
                                        |from the age of, let’s say, four to twelve. The word used in v. 16 for <char style="it">boys and girls</char>|
                                        |(<char style="it">paidia</char>, παιδίον/Strong’s 3813) has a broader meaning than <char style="it">babies.</char>|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Don’t prevent or otherwise hinder the boys and girls from coming to me</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">Let the boys and girls come to me and don’t prevent or otherwise hinder them</char>…The literal|
                                        |wording of the GT breaks apart what could or should otherwise be combined into a single phrase into two|
                                        |phrases joined by the conjunction <char style="it">and. </char>This is a figure of speech, and since|
                                        |the literal wording is awkward, it’s been modified into a single phrase.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Why do you call me ‘good’?</char>…Ref. notes of Matt. 19:17, Mark 10:18.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">The fact is, it’s easier for a camel to crouch down and crawl through a small gate portal|
                                        |than for a rich man to get involved with Him</char>…Lit: <char style="it">For it’s easier for a camel|
                                        |to go into through an eye of a needle than a rich man to enter into God’s kingdom</char>. Ref. note of|
                                        |Matt. 19:24. Luke says <char style="it">go into through an eye of a needle</char>, whereas Matthew says|
                                        |<char style="it">to go throw the eye of a needle </char>(and they use different words for <char style="it">eye|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">needle</char>).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Gentiles</char>…Also: <char style="it">foreigners; the nations</char>. Jesus is pointing|
                                        |out that his crucifixion is even more odious since it’s performed by Gentiles. The Gentiles are unclean;|
                                        |Jews were not supposed to associate with them; there are promises to Israel in the Old Testament of protection|
                                        |from the Gentiles. |

                                        |you didn’t sow</char>. Ref. Matt. 25:24.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">people</char>…Lit: <char style="it">they</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">at this very moment in time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in this day</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">what makes for peace</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the things associated with peace</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">lay you out flat</char>…Lit: <char style="it">dash you to the ground</char>. Figuratively|
                                        |speaking, somewhat.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the timeframe of when you get checked on to see if you’re doing what you’re supposed|
                                        |to do</char>…Lit: <char style="it">season of your visitation</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">designated teachers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Scribes</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">set in good order, preserved the way they’re supposed to be</char>…Lit: <char style="it">salvation</char>.|
                                        |This meaning of the word <char style="it">salvation </char>builds on its usage in the OT (for example,|
                                        |Isa. 12:2; Jer. 3:23; Hab. 3:13), which has added to it additional meanings in the NT.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">$10,000 bill</char>…Lit: <char style="it">ten minas</char>. Some liberties taken. A|
                                        |minas is a Middle-Eastern weight measurement amounting to 1.25 lbs. (0.57 kg) per minas, and for Jewish|
                                        |usage, 1 minas is equal to 100 denarii. A denarius is a day’s labor, or $100 (ref note of Matt. 18:28)|
                                        |in today’s purchasing power. However, since such this is pre-industrial era, the actual affect in ancient|
                                        |times of such purchasing power would make the amount seem greater. In other words, the amount would be|
                                        |similarly regarded as $10,000 would be regarded in a very poor country nowadays.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he’s favored! he’s coming! the king! at Jehovah’s behest</char>…Lit: <char style="it">The|
                                        |one being blessed, the coming one, the king, in the name of the Lord</char>. Liberties taken, as this|
                                        |chant, originally chanted in Aramaic, was translated tersely into Gk. As Gk. is compact due to its uses|
                                        |of inflections, representing nuances in verb tenses, noun cases, etc., it’s impossible to render this|
                                        |word-for-word in English while retaining the succinctness that a chant requires. A chant is as much about|
                                        |rhythm as it is about the actual words. I surmise that since this was a chant, and since chants aren’t|
                                        |necessarily written in the same logical fashion as narratives are, this is one of the causes (though|
                                        |not the only one) for the disagreement in the principal manuscripts as to the precise wording of this|
                                        |verse.|

     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">designated teachers</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Scribes</char>. Ref. note of Matt.|
                                        |2:3.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’ll answer you in just one sentence</char>…Lit: <char style="it">I’ll ask you—even|
                                        |I a word</char>. The literal wording is presented as a figure of speech. Same wording used in Luke 19:42|
                                        |(Lit: <char style="it">if you knew in this day—even you the things with peace</char>).|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">man-made</char>…Lit: <char style="it">from men</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">hurt</char>…<char style="it">badly</char>…Lit: <char style="it">wounded</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">heaven forbid!</char>…Also: <char style="it">may this not be!</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">So now, what about this verse of Scripture</char>…Lit: <char style="it">what, therefore,|
                                        |is this </char>[<char style="it">thing</char>]<char style="it"> which has been written</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">life after death</char>…Lit: <char style="it">resurrection</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">those who go with the flow in this present age</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the sons|
                                        |of this age</char>. Also ref. note of Luke 16:8.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">life after death, don’t you know</char>…Lit: <char style="it">even the resurrection|
                                        |from dead</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">reflections of God’s nature</char>…Lit: <char style="it">sons of God</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">being products of the afterlife</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being sons of the resurrection</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">put your enemies under your subjugation</char>…Lit: <char style="it">put your enemies|
                                        |under your feet</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">A certain man planted a vineyard</char>…Jesus’s parable of the vineyard here is actually|
                                        |a variation of the parable in Isaiah 5:1–7. The Scribes and chief priests were caught up in the telling|
                                        |of the parable (v. 16 <char style="it">Heaven forbid!</char>), instead of thinking on their feet and|
                                        |recollecting the theme of Isaiah’s original parable, which they would’ve surely been familiar with.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Everyone falling upon that stone will be crumbled; whoever it happens to fall on, it|
                                        |will pulverize</char>…Ref. note of Matt. 21:44|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">coin (a denarius)</char>…Lit: <char style="it">denarius</char>. This was a Roman coin.|
                                        |The Jews were forced to use currencies from other nations, but in so doing were benefitting from the|
                                        |Roman system which supported the currency. As beneficiaries of this system, they were obligated to support|
                                        |it through taxation, the point that Jesus makes. In their hypocrisy, they were reaping the benefit but|
                                        |despising the system bestowing it.|

                                        |<char style="it">the powers of the heavens will be shaken</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Man</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Son of Man</char>. Ref. Matt. 8:20.|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">your having things restored for you and your having things put back to the way they’re|
                                        |supposed to be for you is just around the corner</char>…Lit: <char style="it">your redemption draws near</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">generation</char>…This word is taken literally in this context, but on the other hand,|
                                        |perhaps instead it could mean a collection of people of the same mindset or an era of thought in the|
                                        |history of mankind.|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">grow old and fade out of existence</char>…<char style="it">grow old and fade into irrelevance</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">pass by</char>. A NT expression.|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">come all of a sudden and relentlessly oppress you</char>…Lit: <char style="it">stand|
                                        |upon you</char>. The word <char style="it">upon </char>used here in v.34 and also in v.35 has the same|
                                        |meaning as the way it’s used in <char style="it">nation upon nation, kingdom upon kingdom</char> (v.|
                                        |10, lit.), which talks about one group attacking another in some way or fashion.|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">everywhere all over the planet, those simply relaxing and keeping to themselves</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">sitting upon the face of the entire earth</char>. <char style="it">The face of the earth</char>|
                                        |is an idiom used in the OT, Gen. 7:23 for example.|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in all the various circumstances of life and in the change in current events</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">in all seasons</char>|
     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">two dollars</char>…Lit: <char style="it">two leptons</char>. A lepton was the smallest|
                                        |denomination of Greek coin, and is traditionally 1/100 of a drachma, and a drachma is roughly equal to|
                                        |a denarius (ref. note of Matt. 18:28 for denarius conversions).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">claiming to have my authority</char>…Lit: <char style="it">upon my name</char>. Note|
                                        |that it is <char style="it">upon my name </char>rather than <char style="it">in my name</char>, which|
                                        |is used in Mark 16:17 and elsewhere. <char style="it">Upon</char> has connotations of forcefully taking|
                                        |something that belongs to another, as used in v. 10, lit: <char style="it">nation shall be risen up upon|
                                        |nation</char>. Also, ref. notes of Mark 13:6, Matt. 24:4.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">famines &amp; plagues</char>…The two Gk. words used for <char style="it">famine </char>and|
                                        |<char style="it">plague </char>in the phrase <char style="it">limoy</char> <char style="it">kai</char>|
                                        |<char style="it">loimoy </char>(λιμοὶ καὶ λοιμοὶ) are the words <char style="it">limos </char>(λιμός|
                                        |/Strong’s 3042) and <char style="it">loimos</char> (λοιμός /Strong’s 3061) form an alliteration/assonance,|
                                        |giving credence to the notion that this is an expression and as such is a generalization for all sorts|
                                        |of calamities, not confined to the literal meaning “famine and plague.”|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a clamor of the waves and the sea</char>…In the Bible (for example, Rev. 13:1), the|
                                        |sea represents the masses of mankind; random people throughout the globe.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">pull yourselves together and lift your spirits</char>…Lit: <char style="it">straighten|
                                        |up and lift up your heads</char>. <char style="it">Straighten up</char> implies straightening up after|
                                        |a fight. <char style="it">Lift up your heads</char> means to perk up, become optimistic, see the opportunities|
                                        |around you, no longer be downcast, shed your self-abasement.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">With the longings of eager desire, I eagerly desire</char>…Lit: (in Gk.) <char style="it">epithumia|
                                        |epethumasa </char>(Ἐπιθυμίᾳ ἐπεθύμησα), <char style="w" strong="G01939">Ἐπιθυμίᾳ </char>), <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G01937">ἐπεθύμησα</char>). This redundant use of the same word, howbeit in noun and participle|
                                        |forms, is likely an expression, and if not an expression, would be a figure of speech (alliteration/assonance).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">just forget it, ok…</char>Also: <char style="it">enough on this topic</char>…Or: <char|
                                        |style="it">That’ll work</char>…Lit<char style="it">: it is enough</char>. Some ambiguity, as Jesus could|
                                        |be taken to mean “enough of this nonsense” or “that’ll be enough swords.” The former is assumed to be|
                                        |correct, as it is connected to what Jesus said in v. 36: “have him sell his jacket [lit: cloak] and have|
                                        |him buy a sword.” What Jesus meant by this statement of v. 36 is that you’ll no longer need your cloak.|
                                        |Everyone owned a cloak, and most people owned just one, and it was used as a blanket at night—which would|
                                        |be your only blanket too. In the long-term, a cloak was an essential need of life, but in the short-term|
                                        |is not a necessity, like when one is engaged in moderate physical activity, since the body generates|
                                        |enough heat to keep oneself warm without needing a cloak for warmth. The cloak becomes necessary after|
                                        |the activity, of course. The sword refers to going to a war. Together, what v. 36 means is for you to|
                                        |get rid of your cloak since you won’t be needing it anymore, but acquire a sword in its place, since|
                                        |you will be needing that: You’re going to war and you’ll probably be killed. Jesus didn’t literally mean|
                                        |to buy a sword and go off to battle; his meaning was figurative. But the twelve didn’t see it as figurative,|
                                        |taking the statement literally. Jesus didn’t have enough time to explain himself, so he simply dropped|
                                        |the subject by saying “just forget it, ok.”|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verses 43 and 44 are not found in some of the most important manuscripts (KJV: “43And there appeared|
                                        |an angel unto him from heaven, strengthening him. 44And being in an agony he prayed more earnestly: and|
                                        |his sweat was as it were great drops of blood falling down to the ground.”)This passage has always been|
                                        |controversial, and that because of its content. Verse 43 has the same spurious feel to it as John 5:4,|
                                        |and verse 44 has been debated for centuries (see next note).|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">his sweat happened to drip on the ground like when drops of blood from a cut drip on|
                                        |the ground</char>…Jesus didn’t actually sweat drops of blood; this is a simile. The rate at which his|
                                        |drops of sweat dripped onto the ground is compared to the rate at which, say for example, you cut your|
                                        |finger with a knife—the rate at which that cut bleeds. That’s a high rate of perspiration, one which|
                                        |occurs when a person is engaged in highly strenuous exercise, usually complicated by warmer temperatures.|
                                        |The fact that Jesus wasn’t physically moving and that it was chilly enough later in the night for Peter|
                                        |to have to warm himself around a fire makes this extraordinary. On the other hand, there’s dubious (at|
                                        |best) scientific evidence to back up the claim that people under extreme duress sweat blood. It simply|
                                        |does not happen. So if Jesus did actually sweat drops of blood, as many assert, that removes that experience|
                                        |of prayer out of the realm of human experience and into the super-human, even supernatural, and in this|
                                        |instance would have exempted him from suffering as an ordinary human being.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Why do we need to find any more witnesses</char>?…By the Law of Moses, a conviction|
                                        |in the Jewish court required two or three witnesses.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">a Messiah-king</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Christ king</char>|

     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Dear ladies</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Daughters of Jerusalem</char>. More precisely,|

                                        |Solomon 1:5.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Jesus proceeded to say, “Father, forgive them, since they don’t know what they’re doing.”</char>…The|

     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">rolled dice</char>…Lit: <char style="it">cast lots</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assume your preordained position in your kingdom</char>…Lit: <char style="it">come into|

     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">noon</char>…<char style="it">three in the afternoon</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|

     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bright, colorful, beautiful clothing</char>…In ancient times, kings, noblemen, and the|
                                        |rich were distinguished from the peasants by wearing this sort of clothing; hence Herod’s mocking of|
                                        |Jesus’s kingship.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 17 omitted by the better manuscripts|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">If they’re doing these things with pieces of freshly-cut lumber, then whatever happened|
                                        |to the dried-out pieces</char>?…The lumber Jesus is referring to is the lumber used to make a cross.|
                                        |The answer to Jesus’s question, <char style="it">what happened to the dried-out pieces, </char>is that|
                                        |the dried-out pieces are already in use with bodies still hung on them being crucified. As a result,|
                                        |there are no more pieces of wood lying around which can be used to crucify everyone who’s about to be|
                                        |crucified. The Romans crucified criminals on a regular basis, and undoubtedly reused the same crosses|
                                        |over and over, keeping them in a back room or a warehouse, as this would be easier than finding wood|
                                        |and building a cross each time a criminal needed to be crucified. So they kept enough crosses in storage|
                                        |to handle the day-to-day crucifixions, and these crosses are the “dried-out<char style="it"> </char>pieces”<char|
                                        |style="it"> </char>referred to in this verse. However, there were instances when the Romans performed|
                                        |mass-crucifixions, and the fall of Jerusalem in 70AD would be one such instance. In that case, they wouldn’t|
                                        |have been enough crosses in storage to perform all the crucifixions, as the roads would be lined for|
                                        |miles with those crucified. In that case, they’d have to cut down trees to get the lumber needed for|
                                        |all the crucifixions, hence the “pieces of freshly-cut lumber.”|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">It was a preparation day, preparation for the Sabbath which would start the following|
                                        |day, and the sun was about to set and consequently begin the next day, the Sabbath</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">It was a preparation day, and it was </char>[<char style="it">starting to</char>]<char style="it">|
                                        |dawning a Sabbath</char>. Though the Gk. word for <char style="it">dawn </char>is used in the verse,|
                                        |scholars agree that this is referring to the beginning of a new day, which for the Jews is evening, not|
                                        |morning, and not sunrise per se. Some liberties taken with the wording to make this clearer to the reader.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The sentence begun at the end of this chapter is completed in the next chapter.|

                                        |up </char>rather than <char style="it">enter in</char>; it’s inferred that these things came up from|
                                        |the ground, and the ground is where base, negative, carnal, and evil things of life originate, as insinuated|
                                        |in other parts of the Bible.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Out of the joy, wonder, and marvel of it all, they just couldn’t believe it</char>…This|
                                        |is partly true in a literal sense and partly a figure of speech (ref. Matt. 28:17 for a parallel figure|
                                        |of speech). They believed him but were too stunned to believe him entirely, so he supplied more evidence|
                                        |for their physical senses.|

******************  JOHN   **************

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  JOHN Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |John’s Gospel stands apart from the other three—Matthew, Mark, and Luke, the Synoptic Gospels—in more|
                                        |ways than one. It’s content is different, it’s chronology is different. The Greek that John uses is very|
                                        |simple and is, for the most part, readily translated word-for-word into English. However, underneath|
                                        |the simplistic wording is an enigmatic book which makes vague, abstract generalizations it does not explain.|
                                        |John’s epistles are even more simplistic yet enigmatic and vague.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |On the one hand, John’s writing needs a good copy editing. Among other things, he uses the wrong verb|
                                        |tenses, is too ambiguous, assuming that the reader will have no problem filling in the missing content.|
                                        |Had I submitted something comparable to the way that John writes as a high school term paper, my English|
                                        |teachers would’ve marked it all up in red.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |On the other hand, John has his own peculiar meaning of words and phrases that differ from everything|
                                        |else in the NT and which can only be learned by studying his writings, the simple, vague phrases which|
                                        |are enigmatic and profound. In fact, from a language perspective, John’s Gospel should be viewed in a|
                                        |separate light from the remainder of the NT, so different is his writing. Inside this simple fisherman|
                                        |was a deeply spiritual man, one who was Semitic and not Western, one who used words and grammatical constructs|
                                        |his own ways and not the way everyone else does.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Of all the books in the NT, John’s Gospel has enjoyed preeminence from the days of the early church.|
                                        |This is proven by the fact that the oldest surviving manuscripts NT manuscripts, and the most numerous|
                                        |of the oldest, are of John. And if Matthew was written to Jews, Mark to Romans, Luke to Greeks, then|
                                        |John was written to Christians.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">In the beginning</char>…Lit (Gk): <char style="it">en archai </char>(Ἐν ἀρχῇ), <char|
                                        |style="w" strong="G01722">Ἐν</char>), <char style="w" strong="G00746">ἀρχῇ</char>). Same two-word introduction|
                                        |as is found in Gen. 1:1 of the Septuagint; this is not a coincidence. The rendering therefore the typical|
                                        |English Bible’s Genesis beginning so that the reader would notice the similarity. Otherwise, variations|
                                        |in translation could render <char style="it">en archai</char> as “in ancient times” or something like|
                                        |that, as the definite article is missing from <char style="it">beginning, </char>which means there’s|
                                        |no specific beginning epoch referred to.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Concept</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Word</char>. <char style="it">Concept</char>|
                                        |(short for <char style="it">Conception</char>)<char style="it"> </char>taken from H.D.F. Kitto’s book|
                                        |<char style="it">The Greeks</char>: “In the works of Man, Reason and Perfection assume a symmetrical|
                                        |form…The Greek for Reason, in the present sense, is ‘logos’, from which the adjective ‘logical’. ‘Logos’|
                                        |is usually mistranslated ‘word’: is rather ‘speech’, or, the idea which is conveyed by speech. ‘In the|
                                        |beginning was the Word’ really means ‘In the beginning was the Conception’…Here is the culmination of|
                                        |the search made by Greek thinkers for the inner reality, the ‘logos’; The Word was God.” Also, ref. note|
                                        |of Rom. 10:8.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the midst of it all the light shined</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the light shines</char>.|
                                        |The use of the present tense for the past tense is a common figure of speech used in the Gospels. Ref.|
                                        |note of Luke 17:37. |
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |But for this verse, this is a special figure of speech, a subcategory of the usage of present for past,|
                                        |one where in two consecutive, related clauses (first clause: <char style="it">the light shines in the|
                                        |Darkness</char>; second clause: <char style="it">the Darkness couldn’t take it down</char>), the first|
                                        |clause uses the present tense, but is understood by the reader to be the past tense, and the following|
                                        |clause uses the past tense as expected. This same figure of speech is used in Rev. 12:4a, Rev. 13:14b.|
                                        |The usage of such a figure of speech begs the question: what idea, notion, etc. is the writer communicating|
                                        |beyond the face-value meaning of the words? Some guesswork is involved, but it appears that the present|
                                        |tense in the first clause is similar to some of the modes of the imperfect tense, where in the imperfect|
                                        |directs the reader to pause and ponder what was going on as the event was unfolding. In the present-then-past-tense|
                                        |clauses, the present tense seems to emphasize a difficulty of some sort—perhaps even a long, drawn-out|
                                        |ordeal—and the follow-up past tense clause states with emphasis the outcome of the difficulty.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">set up camp</char>…Lit: <char style="it">dwelled in a tent </char>or <char style="it">pitched|
                                        |tent</char>. Hearkens back to the days of Abraham and also to the sojourning in the wilderness when the|
                                        |people of God lived in tents. As such, it is a Figure of Speech, one used here and there in the Bible.|
                                        |Ref. note of Luke 16:9. It also indicates that Jesus was only to take on flesh and live among us for|
                                        |a brief period of time, then he would—like a nomad—fold up his tent one day, break camp, and go somewhere|
                                        |else.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in tight with the Father</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being in the bosom of the Father</char>.|
                                        |Same word <char style="it">bosom </char>used for <char style="it">the bosom of Abraham</char>; it is|
                                        |the same concept. Ref. note of Luke 16:22.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Judean Jews</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Judeans</char> or <char style="it">the|
                                        |Jews</char>. John uses this word several times when he writes. It can be translated <char style="it">Jews|
                                        |</char>or <char style="it">Judeans </char>depending on the context. When translated <char style="it">Jews,|
                                        |</char>it refers to Jews in general, non-Gentiles. When translated <char style="it">Judeans </char>(ref|
                                        |John 2:18, 3:1 for example), it refers to the Jews who live in Judean, as opposed to Jews who live in|
                                        |Galilee, etc. Also by referring to Judeans, the implication is that these are the Jews who occupy the|
                                        |positions of power in Israel.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">up to a keg or a keg and a half apiece</char>…Lit: <char style="it">up to two or three|

     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">on a Tuesday</char>…Lit: <char style="it">with</char> <char style="it">the Third Day</char>.|
                                        |John’s use of the attributive form of the adjective in conjunction with the definite articles means that|
                                        |he’s referring to something which he’s confident that the reader will know about. In fact, <char style="it">the|
                                        |Third Day </char>is a variation of <char style="it">the third of the Sabbaths; </char>ref. notes of Math|
                                        |28:1, Mark 16:2, 1 Cor. 16:2.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I have no beef with you, lady</char>…Lit: <char style="it">me and you, woman</char>;|
                                        |and expanding the inflections, <char style="it">to me and to you, woman</char> (<char style="it">me</char>|
                                        |and <char style="it">you</char> are in the dative case; the addition of the preposition <char style="it">to|
                                        |</char>is necessary when rendered to English). <char style="it">Me and you </char>is an expression used|
                                        |in the NT, and appears in Matt. 8:29, Mark 1:24, Mark 5:7, Luke 8:28 (and perhaps more). Its meaning|
                                        |is deduced by its usage in these various verses.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I have no beef with you, lady—my time has not yet arrived!</char>…This is the first|
                                        |miracle Jesus ever performed (ref. v. 12), and it’s significant that it occurred at a wedding. This wedding|
                                        |has a symbolic meaning, and what Jesus says here addresses the symbolism of the event. The wedding symbolizes|
                                        |God’s plan for the human race. God intended all of mankind to live life as though it were one long wedding|
                                        |celebration of a sort, but then sin entered into the world and spoiled the party. Wine is what generates|
                                        |the frivolity and lightens the mood, causing the guests to loosen up and celebrate. Wine symbolizes the|
                                        |means by which mankind can enter into life’s celebration. But also, as red wine has a color similar to|
                                        |blood, at the same time it’s symbolic of the blood Jesus shed on our behalf. The symbolism is this: the|
                                        |party is over until someone supplies the wine (the blood), which brings life back to a dead party. When|
                                        |Mary tells Jesus they have no wine, on the symbolic level, she’s telling him to give the blood which|
                                        |will restore the human race to its festivities. This is why Jesus replied, <char style="it">my time has|
                                        |not yet arrived</char>—the time for him to shed his blood had not yet arrived.|

                                        |baptism that John the Baptist performed. The water symbolizes a change in lifestyle. The spirit is the|
                                        |spiritual experience of regeneration which a person must undergo at the same time. In this regeneration,|
                                        |a person is reborn spiritually and the Holy Spirit comes and dwells in his regenerated spirit which is|
                                        |inside of him. The two, water and spirit, are the two elements of Christianity that go hand-in-hand:|
                                        |a change to live the right way and a spiritual life, a life in the Spirit.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the wind blows</char>…Also: <char style="it">the Holy Spirit breathes wherever He pleases,|
                                        |and you hear the sound He makes, but you don’t know where He comes from or where He’s going to</char>|
                                        |.The Gk. word used for <char style="it">wind </char>here is <char style="it">pneuma </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G04151">πνεῦμα</char>), the same one used for <char style="it">spirit; </char>and since the definite|
                                        |article precedes <char style="it">pneuma, </char>it would be <char style="it">Holy Spirit </char>instead|
                                        |of <char style="it">spirit. </char>Jesus is referring to both the actual wind and the Holy Spirit in|
                                        |this sentence.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">takes possession of</char>…Also: <char style="it">is having</char>. First, <char style="it">is|
                                        |having</char> means that this is the moment when the woman is no longer under the authority of her father|
                                        |but instead comes under the authority of her husband. Second, it means directly or insinuates indirectly|
                                        |that the groom is having sex with the bride.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">hardly anybody at all</char>…Lit: <char style="it">nobody</char>, as in the fuller context,|
                                        |<char style="it">Nobody received his testimony. </char>(v.33)<char style="it"> The one who received his|
                                        |testimony sealed that God is true. </char>Note how John says in v. 32 that nobody received his testimony,|
                                        |then states the opposite in v.33, that some did receive his testimony. The word <char style="it">nobody|
                                        |</char>is not to be taken literally; it is a figure of speech which is something like a combination of|
                                        |a synecdoche and an hyperbole. A key to detecting this figure of speech is that the contradiction occurs|
                                        |immediately after the premise. In this case the word <char style="it">nobody </char>is followed up just|
                                        |a few words (not a few verses) later in v.32 with <char style="it">the one who received his testimony.|
                                        |</char>John uses this figure of speech a few times in both his Gospel and in his epistles, and it can|
                                        |confuse the reader if he is unaware that this is a figure of speech, and to be taken with a grain of|
                                        |salt and not literally. A usage of a figure of speech similar to this in English might be: <char style="it">I|
                                        |posted all of the pictures of my vacation on social media, and—like—nobody commented on them. But the|
                                        |two people who did…</char>|

     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the true way: in spirit</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in spirit and truth</char>.|

     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">What are you up to?</char>…Lit: <char style="it">What are you looking for?</char>|

     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stop with the tunnel-vision and look at what’s going on around you</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">lift up your eyes</char>|

     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spectacular miracles</char>…Lit: <char style="it">signs and wonders</char> (v.48); <char|
                                        |style="it">sign</char> (v. 54)|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">held their worship services</char>…Lit: <char style="it">worshipped</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken, as the worship John is referring to are the appearances before priests at the temple in Jerusalem,|
                                        |where animals were offered as sacrifices, etc., and not a church or synagogue service as we know it.|
                                        |The feud between the Jews and the Samaritans originated years ago when the northern tribes of Israel|
                                        |under Rehoboam (and the Samaritans are descended from them) severed ties with Judah. A political problem|
                                        |arose for Rehoboam, in that the temple was in Jerusalem, which is in Judah. He figured if his newly-seceded|
                                        |kingdom were to continue their pilgrimages to the Jerusalem temple, their sentiments and affections,|
                                        |and hence their political loyalty, would eventually return to Judah. For this reason, Rehoboam instituted|
                                        |religious observances in the north; this Samaritan woman refers to this.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">worship</char>…Jesus refers to worship, both to the OT and the NT forms of worship.|
                                        |The OT worship consisted of appearances before priests at the temple, which included (but was not limited|
                                        |to) sacrificial offerings. NT worship is not like that; NT worship in its essence is spiritual. Humans|
                                        |are spiritual beings, God is a spirit, and we offer Him worship out of our spirits. No physical forms|
                                        |are necessary to do this, but man with his religious tendencies yields to the temptation of supplanting|
                                        |spiritual worship with physical or emotional forms.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">feeble with sicknesses of one sort or another</char>…Lit: <char style="it">weak</char>.|
                                        |Commonly used word in the NT to describe a person who’s run-down with an unknown medical condition, as|
                                        |they couldn’t diagnose diseases back then very well. Ref. note of Matt. 4:23.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">While it’s agitated and I’m on my way to the pool, someone else cuts in front of me</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">In it I’m going another goes down in front of me</char>. Assumption is that, since this|
                                        |is a conversation, the man omitted a few words.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">all of this…this</char>…Lit: <char style="it">these things</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">my Father’s been doing good deeds, and is doing good deeds, and so am I</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">my Father works, and I also work</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the Man</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the Son of Man</char>. Ref. note of Matt. 8:20|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the graveyard</char>…Lit: <char style="it">in the tombs</char>. The Jews buried their|
                                        |dead in tombs, not graves; some liberties taken.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">depart from that place: those who did the good things that one’s supposed to do will|
                                        |depart to an afterlife</char> <char style="it">of that special fullness of life, but those who were in|
                                        |the habit of doing the petty, careless, thoughtless, mean, ugly things that one’s not supposed to do|
                                        |to an afterlife of judgment resulting in a guilty verdict…</char>Lit: <char style="it">And they will|
                                        |go out, those who did the good to a resurrection </char>[<char style="it">a raising up</char>]<char style="it">|
                                        |of life, but those who did the bad to a resurrection </char>[<char style="it">raising up</char>]<char|
                                        |style="it"> of judgment</char>. Ref. note of John 6:40.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">formally assert claims</char>…Lit: <char style="it">testify</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">take to heart and embrace</char>…Lit: <char style="it">receive</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the human race</char>…Lit: <char style="it">man</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spared</char>…Lit: <char style="it">saved</char>|
     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bask</char>…Or: <char style="it">exult</char>; <char style="it">rejoice exceedingly</char>|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">concepts</char>…Lit: <char style="it">word</char>. Ref. note of John 1:1|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sticking to you</char>…Or: <char style="it">dwelling in you</char>|
     o                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">embrace and accept</char>…Lit: <char style="it">receive</char>|
     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">admiration (the praise derived from being one’s pride and joy)</char>…Lit: <char style="it">glory</char>|

     q                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Verse 4 is one of several spurious verses added to the NT well-after the NT was written. Besides missing|
                                        |from best manuscripts of John’s Gospel, it has the familiar characteristics of the spurious embellishments…attempting|
                                        |to protect God’s majesty; more condemnation; odd-sounding miracles. Translated here for reference:|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">For an angel of the Lord from time to time went down into the pool and was agitating|
                                        |the water. So now, the first to get in after the agitation of the water was becoming whole of whatever|
                                        |disease he was having for some time</char>.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">water’s been agitated</char>…For centuries, people have been taking dips in pools, saunas,|
                                        |baths, springs, etc. for therapy, to heal them of whatever ails them. This is the case here. The question|
                                        |here is how the water got agitated (stirred up). Attendants may have stirred it for a few minutes from|
                                        |time to time, or perhaps some of the water was discharged from a feeding aqueduct and as a side-effect|
                                        |of the pool being refilled, the rushing water caused the agitation. |
