  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  GAL Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |After Paul’s usual long-winded introduction, he curtly states the reason he’s writing, namely that the|
                                        |Galatians have abandoned the Gospel for some other gospel. This is the subject of the book. The issue|
                                        |at hand was whether a person could believe in Jesus directly without the additional constraint of becoming|
                                        |Jewish and following all the requirements found in the Law of Moses. An important aspect of Paul’s message|
                                        |was that one could believe in Jesus and remain a Gentile. This in fact is the definition of Christianity|
                                        |as qualified by the New Testament, and equipped with this teaching, Paul went about spreading Christianity|
                                        |throughout the Roman Empire.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |But there remained a faction of Jews who, though they accepted Jesus as the Messiah and believed in him,|
                                        |insisted that adherence to the practices of Judaism was necessary, and therefore rejected Christianity|
                                        |as defined as believing in Jesus without having to follow Jewish practices. The Book of Galatians is|
                                        |Paul refuting and thwarting this heresy. Had he not done so, Christianity as we know it might have died|
                                        |off in the first century.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Galatians is Paul’s thesis of why the Gentiles have access to the promises of God, and not just the Jews.|
                                        |Paul demonstrates that this was God’s plan all along, that the Old Testament promises that this will|
                                        |one day take place, that faith is—and always was—the key to accessing justification, that the Law of|
                                        |Moses is just one step in God’s long-term plan for mankind, that it was at best a stop-gap anyways and|
                                        |at worst an obstacle if approached apart from faith. If Judaism were a house, then Christianity would|
                                        |be an addition built on top of it.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Most of the Greek text is simpler than—say—2 Corinthians, about on par with Romans, but there a few passages|
                                        |which are tricky (4:12–16 for one). The subject material can be difficult to grasp, but once understood,|
                                        |it comes together into a nice, logical framework.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the founding apostles…</char>Lit: <char style="it">those who were apostles before me</char>.|
                                        |In ancient Jewish culture, the default leadership structure was one of seniority, hence the elders of|
                                        |the Sanhedrin. In keeping with this, the original apostles would outrank Paul in seniority, and by this|
                                        |human reasoning, Paul should’ve submitted to them. But that wasn’t God’s plan.|

     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sinners from far-away, Gentile nations</char>…The assumption among Jews was that anyone|

                                        |could they. Of course, the latter assertion, that a Gentile couldn’t have a relationship with God, is|
                                        |refuted by the OT itself in the persons of Rahab and Ruth. What Jesus said in Matt. 15:26 summarizes|
                                        |this preconception—but at the same time Jesus makes an exception for the Gentile Canaanite woman on account|
                                        |of her faith.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">has been delegated the responsibility of caring for and promoting sin</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">a deacon of sin</char>. Note the Gk. word for <char style="it">deacon </char>is used here|
                                        |and not the Gk. word for <char style="it">servant</char> or <char style="it">slave. </char>A survey of|
                                        |the NT shows that a deacon is one who’s been entrusted with an area of responsibility. A servant or slave,|
                                        |on the other hand, follows orders.|

     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">every last thing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the alls</char> [<char style="it">all|
                                        |things</char>]. Common expression, used as a figure of speech, encompassing not just people but things|
     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Westerner</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Greek</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">derived from</char>…Lit: <char style="it">of</char>|
     n                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">receive the Spirit</char>…Same wording used in John 20:22; Acts 8:15, 19; 19:2. Since|
                                        |what Jesus did in John 20:22 is a one-off where his disciples were born again at that moment, what Paul’s|
                                        |referring to here in Galatians is the baptism in the Holy Spirit, what’s in Acts 8:15, etc. This verse|
                                        |gives insight into how one receives the baptism of the Holy Spirit: it’s by “a particular message you|
                                        |heard from the vantage point of faith.”|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">official, authoritative version of the Law of Moses</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |scroll of the Law</char>. An expression used throughout the Bible (Josh. 1:8, 8:34; Heb. 10:7; 2 Kings|
                                        |22:8,11; Deut. 31:26, etc.). This refers to the master scroll, the agreed-upon definitive copy, the original|
                                        |scroll of an ancient book, in this case the Law of Moses. It’s probable that, at least some of the time,|
                                        |it refers to the entire set of the Torah, not just one of its five scrolls. There was originally only|
                                        |one copy of the Torah, and as time went by, more copies were made, but there was only one copy (the “control|
                                        |copy”) which was considered the authoritative one, as the others were potentially flawed to a small degree.|
                                        |In addition to this meaning, <char style="it">book of the Law</char> (scroll of the Law) also serves|
                                        |as a figure of speech which emphasizes the accuracy of a verse or passage which has been quoted and its|
                                        |authority as having come directly from the hand of God.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">governess</char>…Lit: <char style="it">guardian</char>. Some liberties taken.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">assume</char>…Lit: <char style="it">take from another</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Papa</char>…Lit: <char style="it">Abba</char>. Ref. note of Rom. 8:15.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">one</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you</char> (singular). Paul always uses the plural|
                                        |form (an example is in v.6) of you in his letters when referring to the Galatians, Corinthians, etc.|
                                        |And also, Paul sometimes uses <char style="it">you </char>(singular) as <char style="it">one</char>,|
                                        |as it is in this case.|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">worried</char>…Lit: <char style="it">fear</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">prevent you</char> …Lit: <char style="it">lock you out of</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">haven’t you heard what the Law teaches</char>…Lit: <char style="it">you didn’t hear|
                                        |the Law</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he</char>…Lit: <char style="it">it or that</char>. It’s commonplace for nouns describing|
                                        |children or infants to be neuter rather than masculine.|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the carbon-copies of herself which she’s spawned</char>…Lit: <char style="it">her children</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the one who’s spawned us</char>…Lit: <char style="it">who’s our mother</char>|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">subject to the prevalent idea of God accepting you based on how well you follow the|
                                        |list of do’s and don’ts</char>…This phrase <char style="it">elementary principles </char>is used here|
                                        |and also in Col 2:8,20. The meaning of <char style="it">elementary principles</char> should be determined|
                                        |by the context of its appearances in the NT.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the authority and privileges entailed upon a son when he reaches adulthood</char>…The|
                                        |Gk. word for this is usually translated <char style="it">adoption </char>but literally means <char style="it">son-placement.|
                                        |</char>In this context, it’s referring to Jesus coming into the rights and privileges which were reserved|
                                        |for him. This passage starting from v. 1 draws an analogy between a child who is born the son of the|
                                        |lord of a great estate but is raised no differently than a household slave. Once he reaches an age of|
                                        |maturity, he joins his father and becomes a joint-owner of the estate. Jesus underwent this process by|
                                        |being born into this world and having to live under the dictates of the Law—but only for a fixed time|
                                        |interval. The interval expired when he was raised from the dead. At that time he assumed his full privileges|
                                        |as Son of God. This is also what Heb. 1:5 refers to.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Put yourselves in my shoes, since I’m putting myself in your shoes, comrades</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">become as me, since I become as you, brothers</char>. I’m guessing that this is what|
                                        |Paul meant. Same applies for the next few verses.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">your testing</char>…Or: <char style="it">your temptation</char>. Though some manuscripts|
                                        |read <char style="it">my testing</char> instead, the consensus favors the former over the latter. The|
                                        |redacting of the manuscripts in this area goes to show how difficult vv. 12–16 are to make sense of.|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">because, if possible, you plucked out your eyes and gave them to me</char>…Some claim|
                                        |that the “weakness of the flesh” Paul spoke about in v. 13 was a seeing disorder, and that the Galatians|
                                        |wanted to pluck out their eyes and give them to Paul out of sympathy. As difficult as the passage of|
                                        |vv. 12–16 is to interpret, a healthy skepticism is in order. But the context of this passage doesn’t|
                                        |confirm this dubious claim. Verse 15 begins, “why aren’t you happy anymore?”, while verse 16 begins,|
                                        |“So this means I’ve become your enemy…?” No concurrence is found ; the context suggests that this is|
                                        |an idiom.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Jerusalem above</char>…Paul refers to a concept, also called the New Jerusalem, which|
                                        |has its origins in the OT, in Ezekiel, Jeremiah, and Isaiah, and appears in the NT in Rev. 21:12. In|
                                        |the Bible, cities are metonymies for a concentration of those who intensely believe and put into practice|
                                        |a particular doctrine, religion, etc. The present-day Jerusalem of v. 25 is a metonymy for those who|
                                        |expect to obtain righteousness by adhering to the Law, whereas the Jerusalem above represents righteousness|
                                        |through faith in Christ.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  EPH Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |This letter Paul wrote to the Ephesians has become a universal favorite of all Christians from all denominations|
                                        |who have a genuine relationship with Christ. Reading the first half of the first chapter, one immediately|
                                        |sees why Bible studies—in fact, entire seminary courses—are set on this Paul’s letter, as, reading it,|
                                        |one is swept away in a whirlwind of the extend of what God did for us in Christ. The structure is simple,|
                                        |the same word is often repeated, but it communicates profound thoughts—one after another.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Ephesians runs the gamut of spiritual life. The first couple of chapters of the book are about how believers|
                                        |were taken out of sin and given grace beyond their wildest imagination, and will be given even more in|
                                        |the ages to come. The last few chapters are advice on living day by day in our present lives, followed|
                                        |by the war we wage against the devil. All of it is like a sweet pastry which is best consumed a nibble|
                                        |at a time due to its richness.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The context suggests that this is talking about the special abilities God gives to select individuals|

                                        |the generic word for <char style="it">gift </char>(<char style="it">dōron, </char>δῶρον/Strong’s 1435)|
                                        |<char style="it">, </char>which, unlike <char style="it">charisma,</char> has no sense of grace attached|
                                        |to it (ref. note of Rom. 12:6). But this was probably because <char style="it">dōron </char>was used|
                                        |in Ps. 68:18 in the LXX, which is quoted in v. 8, so Paul uses it in reference to this quotation, not|
                                        |because there’s no grace associated with this <char style="it">dōron.</char>|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">ascended to a high place</char>…Lit: <char style="it">ascended to high</char>. A few|
                                        |verses later (v. 10) Paul clarifies what <char style="it">high </char>means: <char style="it">far above|
                                        |all the heavens. </char>This is not so much a physical location as a position of authority.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">instructor</char>…Also: <char style="it">teacher</char>. Ref. note of Acts 15:1. Also|
                                        |note that there is only one definite article before <char style="it">pastor and instructor</char>, whereas|
                                        |apostle, prophet, and evangelist each have their own definite articles. The missing definite article|
                                        |before <char style="it">teacher </char>binds it to <char style="it">pastor.</char>|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">should the time ever come</char>…This seems to be insinuated by the verb tense of <char|
                                        |style="it">attain, </char>but others (in this case, the <char style="it">Expositor’s Greek Testament</char>)|
                                        |claim that the tense of <char style="it">attain </char>“…points to the event [of attaining the unity|
                                        |of the faith] as expected, and not as a mere hypothetical possibility.” According to this reasoning,|
                                        |<char style="it">should the time ever come </char>would be rendered <char style="it">when the time actually|
                                        |does come</char> instead.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">being a full-grown man (i.e., getting our act together) to the point where we reach|
                                        |Christ’s height and body-weight</char> …Lit: <char style="it">to a complete man, to a measure of stature|
                                        |of the fullness of Christ</char>. <char style="it">Complete man </char>is the same idiom/metaphor used|
                                        |in James 3:2. The metaphorical sense of this is signaled by the use of the more specific Gk. word for|
                                        |<char style="it">man, </char>which is<char style="it"> anār </char><char style="w" strong="G00435">ἀνήρ</char>),|
                                        |over the more general <char style="it">anthrōpos </char><char style="w" strong="G00444">ἄνθρωπος</char>).|
                                        |Also, choosing <char style="it">anār </char>over <char style="it">anthrōpos </char>refers to the physical|
                                        |size of a grown-man’s body. The comparison to a full-grown body continues in the phrase <char style="it">to|
                                        |a measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ. </char>Furthermore<char style="it">,</char> <char|
                                        |style="it">complete man </char>also refers to a man’s physical body size. A “complete man” is one who|
                                        |has a full-grown body. The metaphor is that, when our body is fully grown, we will have attained the|
                                        |same height and weight as Christ. The reference to children in v. 14 continues this stature-metaphor.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">to put on</char> <char style="it">once and for all…</char>There is a noteworthy change|
                                        |in verb tense between the verb <char style="it">to put aside </char>in v. 23 (Gk. present tense) and|
                                        |the verb <char style="it">to put on </char>in v. 24 (Gk. aorist tense); the words <char style="it">repeatedly|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">once and for all </char>are insinuated by these tenses. Also, as these two|
                                        |verbs are imperatives, a present-tense imperative is softer than an aorist-imperative. So the command|
                                        |<char style="it">to put on </char>is like an order that an army captain would give to one of his soldiers|
                                        |or that a lord would give to one of his slaves. So the command to put on the new-self is more urgent,|
                                        |abrupt, and forceful than the command to put off the old-self.|

     l                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">anything which itself brings things out in the open and makes them plain to see is light</char>…Or:|
                                        |<char style="it">all which is being manifested is light</char>. Interpreting the Gk. verb tense of <char|
                                        |style="it">is being manifested </char>as a middle voice instead of passive, in order to make sense of|
                                        |this and fit it into the context. Usage of the middle voice like this is extremely rare in the NT (this|
                                        |is skating on thin ice).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">popular songs accompanied by instruments, songs of praise</char>…Lit: <char style="it">psalms|
                                        |and hymns</char>. The Gk. word for <char style="it">psalm </char>means, “to vibrate by touching” (Thayer);|
                                        |“song of praise accompanied on the harp” (Max &amp; Mary); the Gk. word for <char style="it">hymn </char>means,|
                                        |“a song in praise of gods, heroes, and conquerors” (Thayer). Thayer goes on to say (with a quotation|
                                        |from Synesius? embedded), “[the Gk. word for] <char style="it">song </char>is the generic term; [the|
                                        |Gk. words for] <char style="it">psalm </char>and <char style="it">hymn </char>are the specific, the former|
                                        |designating a song which took its general character from the OT Psalms (although not restricted to them,|
                                        |see 1 Cor. 14:15,26), the latter a song of praise. ‘While the leading idea of <char style="it">psalm|
                                        |</char>is a musical accompaniment, and that of <char style="it">hymn </char>praise to God, <char style="it">song|
                                        |</char>is the general word for a song, whether accompanied or unaccompanied, whether of praise or on|
                                        |any other subject. Thus it was quite possible for the same song to be at once <char style="it">psalm,|
                                        |hymn, </char>and <char style="it">song.’ </char>The words occur together in Col. 3:16 and Eph. 5:19.”|
                                        |Also, ref. note of 1 Cor. 14:15.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spiritual songs</char>…The word for <char style="it">spiritual </char>here is the same|
                                        |word used in 1 Cor. 12:1 “concerning spirituals” (see note there) and is also found in 1 Cor. 14:15,37.|
                                        |In both v. 19 here and 1 Cor. 14:15:37, this phrase means a prophetic utterance or the equivalent of|
                                        |a prophetic utterance in the form of tongues and interpretation. A <char style="it">spiritual song</char>|
                                        |is a prophetic utterance which is put to song.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">submit</char>…Ref. note of 1 Pet. 2:18, which explains the Gk. words for <char style="it">submit|
                                        |</char>and <char style="it">obey. </char>A case in point is the usage of <char style="it">submit </char>here,|
                                        |but the usage of <char style="it">obey </char>in 6:1. Wives are told to submit, but children are told|
                                        |to obey.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  PHIL Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The church at Philippi is introduced in Acts 16, where Paul is diverted to Macedonia, where Philippi|
                                        |is, by an angel which told him, “Cut across the Aegean Sea to Macedonia and help us out.” Shortly after,|
                                        |he meets women in Philippi who gathered outside the city by the river, and these women were the basis|
                                        |for the church at Philippi. In fact, of the names mentioned in this letter to the Philippians, only women|
                                        |are found. Scholars speculate whether this church consisted entirely of women at the time Paul wrote|
                                        |this epistle.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |By the tone and content of the letter, the church in Philippi is one of the stronger, more spiritual|
                                        |churches that Paul founded. Because of this, it’s fitting that they be all women, since the low-profile|
                                        |dedication of women such as these has carried Christianity—even before that, going back to Jesus’s ministry—since|
                                        |the beginning, an oft overlooked and seldom noted cause for the strength, vigor, and propagation of Christianity|
                                        |through the millennia.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The letter to this spiritual church contains few rebukes, few corrections concerning doctrine, and is|
                                        |salted with Paul’s tender affections. The lack of quotations from the OT indicates that those whom the|
                                        |letter was addressed to had no affiliation with Judaism, no knowledge of the OT. They were Gentiles through|
                                        |and through.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The GT is smooth, easily converted into another language, but draws on a deep vocabulary.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

                                        |as a short way to imply <char style="it">of him</char>.|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Zeitgeist</char>…Lit: <char style="it">generation</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">will rejoice and will rejoice together</char>…Or: <char style="it">rejoice and rejoice|
                                        |together</char>. The GT is ambiguous, as the present and future forms in this case are identical. Since|
                                        |this is the apodosis of a conditional sentence, it doesn’t matter so much.|
     j                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrade</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brother</char>|
     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">missionary</char>…Lit: <char style="it">apostle</char>|

     m                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">And in light of this, God</char>…Lit: <char style="it">wherefore and God</char>. The|
                                        |word <char style="it">and </char>is associated to <char style="it">wherefore</char>. In NT Gk., It’s|
                                        |common to have <char style="it">and </char>come after a word such as <char style="it">wherefore. </char>This|
                                        |means that <char style="it">and </char>is not associated to <char style="it">God</char>; some translations|
                                        |err in this manner and render these words “Wherefore God also” or “Therefore God, even God” (<char style="it">and|
                                        |</char>appearing as <char style="it">even </char>in this case).|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">out of His generosity gave</char>…Same word <char style="it">to give </char>as is used|
                                        |in 1:29; see note there. It was generous for God to hand over the keys to His kingdom to Jesus, but on|
                                        |the other hand, Jesus earned this by his obedience. Though the word <char style="it">gave </char>as used|
                                        |here points to God’s generosity, it does not negate the fact that Jesus earned a name above every name.|
                                        |God’s generosity was in the fact that He is willing to bestow an enormous amount of power on another|
                                        |person of the Trinity, not holding it for Himself. This is a reason why the three persons in the Trinity|
                                        |are one instead of three. Islam denies the Trinity because it says that the three persons in the Trinity|
                                        |would compete for power, but the insinuation in the word <char style="it">give </char>here is that God|
                                        |the Father out of His generosity won’t vie for power but instead hands it over to the Son.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the circumcision</char>…Many biblical scholars believe that the Philippian church consisted|

                                        |only applies to men. This supports the notion that there are words in the Bible which, on the surface|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  COL Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |As mature, committed, and faithful that the churches in Ephesus and Philippi were, judging by the introductory|
                                        |part of Paul’s letter, the church in Colossae was on par with them, and one might argue more so. The|
                                        |entire first chapter is a discourse on who Jesus is and what he received by means of his death and resurrection.|
                                        |This knowledge is not revealed in the Gospels but is reserved for the epistles and forms a bedrock on|
                                        |the question of who Jesus was and is.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |But by the second chapter, Paul is dropping hints that there are a few, persuasive people among them|
                                        |who are steering them in the wrong direction. We find out that this is in regard to practices of the|
                                        |Law, but the warnings Paul gives are not as severe as what he told the Galatians.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |And Paul repeats the admonishments he gave to wives, husbands, children, and slaves same as what he gave|
                                        |the Ephesian church. He probably told all of his churches this.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |There’s nothing out of the ordinary to be found in the Greek text. A good depth of vocabulary, but Paul|
                                        |doesn’t get into heady points of philosophy one finds in some of his other epistles, which removes that|
                                        |difficulty from the translator’s plate.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

     p                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">thrones, lordships, rulers, or authorities</char>…These are defined in note of 1 Cor.|
                                        |15:24. One infers from this passage and other passages that Paul’s talking about both human and angelic|
                                        |(more specifically, demonic) positions, as we know from Eph. 1:21; 6:12 that “rulers and authorities”|
                                        |refers to demonic beings.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">any warm body to be found anywhere</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to all creation under|
                                        |the heaven</char> [<char style="it">sky</char>]. Liberties taken. <char style="it">Heaven </char>is singular|
                                        |here (plural elsewhere in this chapter) and it has a definite article, so heaven refers to the sky here|
                                        |and not any of the other meanings for the Gk. word for heaven. Like in Mark 16:15, 2 Cor. 5:17 <char|
                                        |style="it">creation </char>is a metonymy which refers to people and not to the actual creation. This|
                                        |phrase “to all creation under the sky” is an idiom. “Under the sky” and smacks of “under the sun” as|
                                        |used in Eccl. 1:9. The entire idiom means that the Gospel was preached to every sort of person there|
                                        |is and every in every kind of place there is.|

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">religious festivals, start of a new month celebrations, or holidays</char>…Lit: <char|
                                        |style="it">festivals or new moons or Sabbaths</char>. These are festivities prescribed by the Law of|
                                        |Moses and are mentioned several times in the OT. An example is the prophet Hosea in Hos. 2:11, “I will|
                                        |also cause all her mirth to cease, her feast days, her new moons, and her Sabbaths, and all her solemn|
                                        |feasts” (KJV). Just as Hosea described these with the word “mirth,” these are all holidays and celebrations,|
                                        |but celebrations and holidays which are commanded by the Law.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">that which is a shadow of what’s to come but the body which casts that shadow is Christ’s</char>…Much|
                                        |of the Law of Moses was arcane rules that only makes sense in light of this clarification, that they|
                                        |were hints, symbols, and foreshadowings of what was to come, but the essence is in Christ. This reinforces|
                                        |what Paul said in Gal. 3:24. |

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  THESS1 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Scholars believe that this epistle here is the first of Paul’s. There are both praises and admonishments,|
                                        |but not as severe as what the Corinthians received.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The longing Paul has to see those “dear to us” (2:8), his “pride and joy” (2:20), the steps he took so|
                                        |that he “wouldn’t a burden on any of you” (2:9) permeate this letter. The longing is reiterated this|
                                        |way: “How can we possibly thank God enough for you for all the joy we’ve been elated with in the presence|
                                        |of God because of you” (3:9).|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |This longing of one Christian to see another Christian has withered and died in the church in America,|
                                        |another indication of her decline.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |But towards the end of the book, a couple of things which seem out of place leap out at the reader. The|
                                        |first is Paul having to address a problem of sexual immorality—and it appears to have been adultery—in|
                                        |the church. Though a spiritual church, it was not without its glaring, peculiar faults. Second is an|
                                        |answer to one of their questions, namely how will they known when the end will come. Perhaps the mystery|
                                        |is not why this church asked this question but why few if any of Paul’s other churches didn’t. |
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The underlying text is consistent with what he sent to the Colossians, as the two churches are similar,|
                                        |and Paul’s writing style is likewise similar.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">go to higher and higher levels</char>…Lit: <char style="it">abound more</char>|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">container</char>…Also: <char style="it">vessel</char>. Like the way it’s used in 2 Cor.|
                                        |4:7, this refers to our body.|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">dignity</char>…Also: <char style="it">honor</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">stepping out of line</char>…Lit: <char style="it">throwing beyond</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">until</char>…Lit: <char style="it">to</char>. As though heading towards a destination.|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">shout of a command</char>…Lit: <char style="it">a call</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">intense, all-consuming feeling of lust</char>…Lit: <char style="it">passion of desire</char>|
                                        |[<char style="it">lust</char>]. It’s normal for a person to have sexual desire, even a strong desire,|
                                        |but Paul’s talking about a desire that’s been amplified beyond normal amounts of sexual desire (strong|
                                        |as that may be). The Gk. word <char style="it">passion </char>is also used to describe the passion of|
                                        |the pain and suffering of death, like the passion of Christ when he was crucified—this is how strong|
                                        |of a word it is. Sexual predators and sex offenders reach this point, the point where their passion of|
                                        |desire takes control of them and they commit criminal acts. A couple notches down, it will also cause|
                                        |the ordinary person to conduct immoral acts.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">not stepping out of line and taking advantage of or defrauding his fellow-comrade in|
                                        |the matter</char>…Applying logic to this statement here from v. 6 in relationship to the passage as a|
                                        |whole, Paul is telling those in the church not to “defraud” their fellow brother in Christ, and this|
                                        |in relationship to sexual morals. There are two possibilities: first, Paul could be talking about a man|
                                        |having an affair with another man’s wife. Second, Paul could be talking about a man sleeping with the|
                                        |young, unmarried daughter of another man. I believe it’s more likely that Paul is talking about the former|
                                        |than the latter. Therefore, the definition of <char style="it">the fornication </char>(v. 3) is adulterous|
                                        |liaisons. This added with the additional evidence from 1 Cor. 5:1 suggest that the word <char style="it">fornication|
                                        |</char>as used in the NT is talking about grossly immoral sexual acts. Or, put another way, when Paul|
                                        |addresses the issue here and in 1 Cor. 5:1, he’s talking about something which is grossly immoral. The|
                                        |church, however, makes no distinction between sexual acts which are grossly immoral and those which are|
                                        |mildly immoral when applying the word <char style="it">fornication. </char>They should.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">having strong likings for other comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brotherly-love</char>.|
                                        |This Gk. word is a compound where the second word <char style="it">love </char>is the Gk. word <char|
                                        |style="it">philos</char> (φίλος /Strong’s 5384) and not <char style="it">agapā </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G00026">ἀγάπη</char>). Philos differs from agapā in that philos is a love for a person because|
                                        |of how likeable they are, whereas agapā sees value in a person sometimes in spite of how unlikeable they|
                                        |are. Note that the word for <char style="it">love </char>at the end of v. 10 is agapā, not philos.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  THESS2 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The Thessalonians’ curiosity about end-time prophecy has made them a favorite by all those down to our|
                                        |present age who pine for answers to eschatology questions. It’s as though this is a follow-up letter|
                                        |to Paul’s response to the first letter, or perhaps another one. Though the second chapter has these answers,|
                                        |from our perspective the answers are cryptic and need second-guessing since we aren’t privy to all the|
                                        |letters exchanged. Perhaps that makes it even more tantalizing and enticing to pore over.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |In the meantime, though, the Thessalonians had fallen on hard times and suffered persecutions. Unlike|
                                        |some of his other epistles, Paul is quick to point out that the wrath of God will come upon those who|
                                        |incite persecution—not the “turn the other cheek” stereotype. Paul closes with a defense of his conduct|
                                        |among them, particularly how hard he worked to earn his keep, and that others must do the same.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The text is typical of Paul’s epistles. Paul uses a wider range of vocabulary than one finds in the Gospels,|
                                        |to put things in perspective.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">this lawlessness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the lawlessness </char><char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G00458">ἀνομία</char>). Gk: <char style="it">anomia</char> (feminine). Note that the Gk. word|
                                        |for Lawless-One in v. 7 is <char style="it">anomos </char>(masculine). Paul’s making a distinction by|
                                        |using these slightly different words: anomia refers to a quality, whereas anomos <char style="w" strong="G00459">ἄνομος</char>)|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">he who restrains</char>…Gk. <char style="it">o katexōn </char>[ὁ κατέχων, <char style="w"|
                                        |strong="G02722">κατέχων</char>)]. This is not quite the same as what’s in v. 6, which is <char style="it">to|
                                        |katexon </char>(τὸ κατέχον, <char style="w" strong="G02722">κατέχον</char>)]<char style="it">. </char>Although|
                                        |the definite articles are both neuter/masculine, the substantive of the first is masculine while the|
                                        |second in neuter. This suggest that it’s “he who restrains” not “the thing that restrains.” Ref. note|
                                        |of v. 7.|

                                        |style="it">traditions</char>|
     h                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">apostasy</char>…The Gk. word <char style="it">apostasia </char><char style="w" strong="G00646">ἀποστασία</char>)<char|
                                        |style="it">. </char>The NASB defines this as “a falling away from the faith.” Some Gk. scholars disagree|
                                        |with this and claim that it means “departure” instead, citing sources such as the <char style="it">Geneva|
                                        |Bible, </char>Tyndale’s translation, the <char style="it">Great Bible</char>, Kenneth Wuest, and John|
                                        |Lineberry. Their reasoning for choosing “departure” over “a falling away” is that <char style="it">aphistāmi|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G00868">ἀφίστημι</char>)<char style="it">, </char>the root verb from which|
                                        |apostasia is derived, means <char style="it">to depart. </char>Furthermore, they say that <char style="it">apostasia|
                                        |</char>(the noun form) only occurs twice in the NT, here in 1 Thess. 2:3 and over in Acts 21:21. Although|
                                        |the context of Acts 21:21 suggests that apostasia means “falling away” rather than “departure,” the critics|
                                        |claim that this isn’t sufficient evidence to negate the core meaning of aphistāmi. However, what these|
                                        |dissenters fail to take into consideration is the use of apostasia in the LXX. Apostasia is found in|
                                        |Josh. 22:22; 2 Chron. 29:19; 2 Chron. 33:19; Jer. 2:19. In all four cases, apostasia means “rebellion,|
                                        |unfaithfulness, backsliding.” In other words, it means the same thing as “a falling away from the faith.”|
                                        |Paul read from the LXX frequently and extensively (it might’ve even been his primary study-Bible), and|
                                        |he was familiar with the occurrences and usages of apostasia in these passages and was mimicking its|
                                        |usage here in v. 3. But in any case, between the LXX and Acts. 21:21, there are five occurrences of apostasia|
                                        |in the Bible apart from 2:3 here. In five of the five occurrences—100% of the time—the meaning of apostasia|
                                        |is “a falling away from the faith.” The sixth must mean the same also, the one here in v. 3.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the thing that restrains him from being revealed in his own time</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the|
                                        |restraint for him to be revealed in his</char> [or <char style="it">its</char>] <char style="it">own|
                                        |time. </char>The “thing that restrains” in v. 7 is the Gk. <char style="it">to katexon </char>(a form|
                                        |of <char style="it">o katexon</char>), where <char style="it">to </char>is the neuter definite article|
                                        |and <char style="it">katexon </char>is the neuter participle form of the verb <char style="it">katexō|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G02722">κατέχω</char>)<char style="it">, </char>which literally means|
                                        |<char style="it">to have down upon.</char>|

 +P  V17              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |<char style="sc">THIS IS THE WAY I WRITE</char><char style="sup">[C]</char>.|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">comrades</char>…Lit: <char style="it">brothers</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spread rapidly</char>…Lit: <char style="it">run</char>|

     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bylaws, code of conduct, and best-practices established in perpetuity</char>…Lit: traditions|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mooch any meals from anyone</char>…Lit: <char style="it">ate a gift-bread from anyone</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">throughout every circumstance in every place</char>…Lit: <char style="it">through all|
                                        |in all place</char>. The GT is more poetic.|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have a meal at mealtime</char>…Lit: <char style="it">eat</char>. When people congregated,|
                                        |they had a couple people cook for the entire group, because that was the most efficient way of handling|
                                        |food preparation up until modern times. Everyone would sit down at a table together at the same time,|
                                        |the food would be passed around, and it would all be shared. This proscription is to forbid a person|
                                        |from having a seat at the table and share in the meal if he didn’t share in the common work also.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">goofing off</char>…Lit: <char style="it">being a busybody; meddling</char>. The Gk.|
                                        |word literally means “to go around the periphery of work.” The picture is of someone going here or there|
                                        |when working—or supposedly working. Instead, he’s bothering other people who are working, striking up|
                                        |non-work-related conversations, instead of getting his own work done. The assertion that this is what|
                                        |this Gk. means is confirmed by the statement in v. 12 which says to “keeping quiet while working.” Nothing|
                                        |has changed since ancient times!|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM1 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Paul’s instructions to one of his closest assistants, his “dear son” Timothy, has been broadened into|
                                        |guidelines which all Christian churches should follow. Paul doesn’t just give sterile rules to do this,|
                                        |that, and the other, but gets into the details of what’s going on inside the hearts and minds of various|
                                        |people—especially the nefarious ones, adding a lot of color to the epistles he sent to Timothy.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The text is typical of Paul: mastery of Greek, an extensive vocabulary, Western thought, ambiguous in|
                                        |parts due to its brevity or to knowledge privy to the writer and the reader.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Deāsis <char style="w" strong="G01162">δέησις</char>)—a prayer which asks for wants or needs; urgent|
                                        |requests|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Proseuchā <char style="w" strong="G04335">προσευχή</char>)—lit: <char style="it">speaking out to</char>.|
                                        |This is the general word for prayer. Since a secondary meaning is a place of prayer, it insinuates prayers|
                                        |done in that setting, hence: formal prayers; structured prayers; prayers done at a set time.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Enteuksis <char style="w" strong="G01783">ἔντευξις</char>)—lit: <char style="it">a falling in with; a|
                                        |meeting with; a coming together; a conference or conversation</char>. The word is rendered <char style="it">intercession.|
                                        |</char>This kind of prayer insinuates a back-and-forth exchange between two parties; some sort of negotiation.|
                                        |The negotiations can be to suspend a judgment incurred because of a violation of the rules or other just|
                                        |circumstances, such as when Abraham negotiated with God to spare Sodom and Gomorrah. In Abraham’s case,|
                                        |the intercession was done on behalf of another party, but intercession can be done for one’s own self.|
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Eucharistia <char style="w" strong="G02169">εὐχαριστία</char>)—The giving of thanks to God, which is|
                                        |a kind of prayer.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in an exotic hairstyle and with ultra-expensive gold jewelry or pearls or expensive|
                                        |clothing</char>…Lit: <char style="it">braided hair and gold or pearls or expensive clothing</char>. As|
                                        |what Paul writes here is identical to what Peter writes in 1 Pet. 3:3, this implies that this was a problem|
                                        |in the early church. Since Paul precedes this by saying that women should dress in good taste, modestly,|
                                        |and exercise good judgment and self-control, it stands to reason that these hairstyling, jewelry, and|
                                        |expensive clothes were not considered to be good taste, modest, or indicative of one exercising good|
                                        |judgment. Since we in modern times don’t consider the use of hairstyling, jewelry, etc. to be bad taste|
                                        |or indicative of a lack of judgment (except for a few very conservative denominations, most of which|
                                        |have reversed their position), this warrants closer examination. |
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Let’s assume that the amount of gold in piece a jewelry is equivalent to the gold in a Roman Aureus (8g|
                                        |of gold), which was valued at 25 Denarii, and let’s assume each Denarius represented a day’s labor. If|
                                        |there are 312 working days in a years, this represents around 8% of a laborer’s annual income. So from|
                                        |the perspective of us in modern times, if a person earns $50,000 a year, an 8g piece of gold jewelry|
                                        |would cost around $5000 in today’s money (and the same 8g of gold goes for around $500 nowadays). This|
                                        |means that gold jewelry was more expensive for them back then that it is for us, as this hypothetical|
                                        |example shows an 8-to-1 difference then to now.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |So it was more expensive, in terms of purchasing power, for the average woman to dress in the way that|
                                        |Peter and Paul admonish them not to than it is for a woman to dress herself today in the same way. It|
                                        |may be that these women were spending outrageous amounts of money on their dress, and from the remarks|
                                        |Peter and Paul made, were investing their self-image in their ability to dress lavishly and were trying|
                                        |to imitate the world, including the lasciviousness of worldly women.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The lesson that modern-day Christian women should learn is to recognize the root-problems here and not|
                                        |be so concerned about the letter of the law. Women shouldn’t be obsessed with dressing in clothing that|
                                        |they can’t afford, trying to imitate those in the world who live an ungodly life, or base their self-image|
                                        |on the way they look. Being beautiful on the inside is more important than trying to make oneself beautiful|
                                        |on the outside.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">woman</char>…The Gk. words rendered <char style="it">man</char> and <char style="it">woman</char>|
                                        |are <char style="it">anār</char> <char style="w" strong="G00435">ἀνήρ</char>) and <char style="it">gunaika|
                                        |</char><char style="w" strong="G01135">γυνή</char>), which are also the same words rendered <char style="it">husband</char>|
                                        |and <char style="it">wife</char>. The ambiguity (ambiguity…I thought Gk. was this ultra-specific language?)|
                                        |is resolved by context. When Paul leaves instructions for the anār and the gunaika in Ephesians and Colossians,|
                                        |the context is obvious: the rendering is husband and wife. Here also the rendering is context-dependent.|
                                        |Is Paul talking about husbands and wives or men and women? Most translations choose men and women. To|
                                        |justify it being husbands and wives, there must be something in the context that indicates that this|
                                        |is the case. The evidence in that favor is that vv. 11,12 are similar to 1 Cor. 14:33–36, which we know|
                                        |was addressed to wives. Also, v. 15 talks about bearing children, which means that it’s addressed to|
                                        |wives. The subject is omitted from the sentence of v. 15, relying on the verb conjugation in conjunction|
                                        |with the context to insinuate that the subject is <char style="it">she. </char>It Gk., it’s not common|
                                        |to have the subject omitted entirely. In lieu of its total omission, a definite article is used as a|
                                        |pronoun, as a definite article is short, perhaps is even a proclitic. But by omitting the subject entirely,|
                                        |the writer assumes that the reader knows beyond any doubt that the subject to be used is easily insinuated|
                                        |by the context. Such is the case. Through this insinuation, v. 15 is tightly bound to the context. Therefore,|
                                        |since v. 15 addresses wives, not women, coupled with the similarity between this passage and 1 Cor. 14:33–36,|
                                        |one may put forth a weighty argument that the entire context of vv. 11–15 is of wives specifically, not|
                                        |of women in general.|
     D                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">total submissiveness</char>…Lit: <char style="it">all submission</char>. Ref. notes|
                                        |of Eph. 5:22; 1 Pet. 2:18 which explain the difference between <char style="it">submit </char>and <char|
                                        |style="it">obey.</char>|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">give instructions for what a person should or shouldn’t do</char>…Also: <char style="it">teach</char>.|
                                        |The Gk. word <char style="it">didaskō</char> (διδάσκω/Strong’s ). The meaning of this word extends beyond|
                                        |mere definition of the English word <char style="it">to teach</char>, and includes giving instruction|
                                        |as to what rules a person must follow. It’s used this way in Acts 15:1 (ref. note there). Since what|
                                        |follows the word didaskō here in v. 12 is “dominate” and “give orders,” it stands to reason that didaskō|
                                        |is used in this context to refer to giving instructions on what rules one should follow more so than|
                                        |meaning teaching (explaining).|
     E                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |Now, in vv. 13, 14, Paul gives the reasons why a woman shouldn’t be giving instruction. First is the|
                                        |fact that Adam was created before Eve and is therefore receives the leadership position. Second, women|
                                        |are more easily deceived, more so than men (cults usually have more women than men, for example), and|
                                        |for this reason are less qualified to be instructors. In spite of this, Titus 1:3 allows women to be|
                                        |teachers.|
     F                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">Plus Adam was not deceived by the serpent but the woman, once deceived, found herself|
                                        |in transgression</char>…We must keep in mind that Paul credits Adam—not Eve—with the original sin (Rom.|
                                        |5:14), in spite of centuries of Christian teaching to the contrary. Though both Adam and Eve sinned in|
                                        |the garden, Adam was not deceived when he partook of the forbidden fruit, and this makes his sin more|
                                        |heinous than Eve’s, as—according to this verse here—he knew exactly what he was doing when he bit the|
                                        |fruit. It was bold-faced disobedience in light of the full understanding and recollection of God’s commandment.|
     G                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">spared calamity through the childbearing</char> <char style="it">years</char> …Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">saved the childbearing</char>. The Gk. word <char style="it">saved </char>rendered <char|
                                        |style="it">spared calamity </char>here is not in reference to her receiving Christ. Some that this is|
                                        |a promise for a woman escape death or harm when giving birth, which up until modern times was a serious|
                                        |threat to a woman’s well-being.|

                                        |style="it">Spirit</char>. Though the GT is ambiguous, the preceding stanza’s “in the flesh” skews the|
                                        |resolution to <char style="it">in spirit </char>rather than <char style="it">in the Spirit.</char>|
     i                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">the husband of one woman</char>…This covers both polygamy (incidentally) and marriage,|
                                        |divorce, then remarriage (primarily). Many interpret this proscription as applying to polygamy, but polygamy|
                                        |wasn’t practiced in the parts of the Roman Empire where Paul’s churches were. Furthermore, in 5:9 when|
                                        |Paul is talking about widows, he says that she should be “the wife of one man.” This is the same wording|
                                        |in GT as “husband of one woman,” except in reverse. If “husband of one woman” were talking about polygamy—in|
                                        |this case, a single man having multiple wives at the same time—then “wife of one man” would have to be|
                                        |talking about a single woman having multiple husbands at the same time—something which is unheard of.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">mystery</char>…The “mystery of piety” here and the mystery of “Christ in you, the hope|
                                        |of glory” (Col. 1:27) refines the definition of <char style="it">mystery </char>as used in the NT: a|
                                        |“mystery” is something which is profound.|

     k                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">overpowered with physical, sensual desires contrary to their vow to Christ</char>…The|
                                        |single Gk. word rendered <char style="it">overpowered with physical, sensual desires</char> is a word|
                                        |Paul coins here, not found anywhere else. Paul may be referring to sexual desire, or he may be referring|
                                        |to the desire of a woman to become more affluent through marriage, which would bring those extra creature-comforts|
                                        |she misses in her poverty (or both perhaps.) To this second point, the root for this Gk. word appears|
                                        |in Rev. 18:7,9, and is rendered <char style="it">luxury </char>there.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">paraded before them with much fanfare for everyone to see in front of them on their|
                                        |way to judgment; but some come right behind them, quietly, unannounced, and unexpected by everyone</char>…Lit:|
                                        |<char style="it">going before to judgment; but some follow right behind</char>. A metaphor of the victory|
                                        |parade of a general who’s won a great victory and wishes to flaunt his victory when he marches into the|
                                        |city. The procession is orchestrated so that, when arriving in the city, the spoils of war, the glitz,|
                                        |the glamor go first. This is done to attract attention and applause and to drum up awe and excitement.|
                                        |Then comes the general. After him comes the slaves he’s captured, etc. They get little attention. In|
                                        |the metaphor, the sins of some people are well-known, everyone has talked and talked about them, dissecting|
                                        |every bit of the evil deed. But the sins of some people are a well-kept secret, but they will make their|
                                        |way to judgment.|

                                        |different-teach.” This word only appears twice in the NT; Paul appears to have coined it. From the sound|
                                        |of it, he’s describing those who teach things which are perhaps novel, appealing, and sound good on the|
                                        |surface. Paul isn’t saying they are necessarily false teachings, they’re just different and warrant keeping|
                                        |a close eye on, because there may be a false doctrine lurking under the guise of a new, welcoming message.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM2 Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |The strong emotions which Paul had while in prison are put in this second letter to Timothy, Paul’s final|
                                        |letter. One can feel the intensity when reading it, feeling something in the air, feeling that things|
                                        |are getting serious, that events have taken a turn for the worse, that the end is near. He breaks out|
                                        |into poem in the second chapter an prayer in the fourth.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Paul’s attachment to his son in the Faith Timothy is one of the few things which gives him the inner|
                                        |strength to persevere; except for Luke he is alone.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TIM2 Chapter 1  <<<<<<<<<<<<
 +   V 1              VERSES_NARRATIVE: |Paul, <char style="it">an </char>apostle of Christ Jesus because of God’s will according to <char style="it">the|

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">utterly captivate</char>…Lit: <char style="it">take captive as a prisoner of war</char>.|
                                        |A metaphor.|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">silly women who are led</char>…The noun for <char style="it">silly women </char>is neuter,|
                                        |the participle <char style="it">led</char> is also neuter, like the participle for <char style="it">have|
                                        |a pile of sins</char>; therefore the antecedent of <char style="it">led </char>is <char style="it">silly|
                                        |women.</char> For that matter <char style="it">learning </char>in v. 7 is also neuter.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">have known</char>…Lit: <char style="it">know</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">in the ways of</char>…Lit: <char style="it">unto</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">sneak into the houses</char>…If one thinks about this more closely, the men described|
                                        |here who sneak into these women’s homes must do so with the cooperation and consent of the women. In|
                                        |other words, they cannot be burglars breaking into a house, as the door would be kept locked at night,|
                                        |the woman would scream (Deut. 22:24, though these are Gentiles), the man of the house (and there certainly|
                                        |would have been) would rescue her, etc. But the woman could find a time when nobody else was home, a|
                                        |time for the man to enter the house for a romantic rendezvous, adulterous or just consensual. Naturally,|
                                        |the man would have to be careful not to be seen entering the house, hence Paul’s use of the word <char|
                                        |style="it">sneak</char>.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">silly women</char>…Lit: <char style="it">little women; </char>more precisely <char style="it">women-ettes</char>|
                                        |[the diminutive form of the word <char style="it">women</char>]. This word only appears once in the NT,|
                                        |and the lexicons provide little information about it, except to say that it’s pejorative. The fact that|
                                        |it’s a diminutive leads one to speculate that it’s slang of a sort. The closest equivalent might be the|
                                        |word <char style="it">bimbo, </char>though that might be too strong a word. We can only guess what the|
                                        |exact meaning is.|

  >>>>>>>>>>>>>>  TITUS Introduction  <<<<<<<<<<<<
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Titus, though not mentioned by name much in the NT, was nevertheless an assistant Paul relied heavily|
                                        |on. The amount Paul relied on such assistants (“deacons” in fact) becomes apparent from reading this|
                                        |epistle and Paul’s epistles to Timothy, as his churches were spread out through the Roman Empire. What|
                                        |Paul tells Titus is similar—almost exactly the same in points—to what he tells Timothy, and from this|
                                        |we can deduce that the guidelines Paul established for running the churches were uniform.|
                     NON_VERSE_CONTENT: |Though Titus is not quoted as much as other books, it is a hidden gem lying in the rough, waiting for|
                                        |the curious treasure-seeker to spot it, pick it up, wipe the dirt off it, and place it amongst his collection.|
                 SPACER_BEFORE_CHAPTER: ||

     a                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">time immemorial</char>…Lit: <char style="it">eternal times</char>|
     b                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">individual periods of human history</char>…Lit: <char style="it">their own seasons</char>.|
                                        |Same phrase used in 1 Tim. 2:6;6:15.|
     c                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">son</char>…Or: <char style="it">child</char>|
     d                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">tried-and-true message</char>…Lit: <char style="it">trustworthy word</char>|
     e                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">vicious brutes</char>…Lit: <char style="it">evil animals</char>|
     f                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">fat blimps</char>…Lit: <char style="it">free-from-labor bellies</char>. Some liberties|
                                        |taken. The <char style="it">Expositor’s Greek Testament</char> says, “He [the poet] has in his mind the|
                                        |belly, as it obtrudes on the beholder and is a burden to the possessor.”|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">I’m quoting a reliable source</char>…Lit: <char style="it">the testimony itself is true</char>|
     g                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: ||
     A                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">bishop</char>…Ref. note of 1 Cor. 15:24. As vv. 5–6 address qualifications for elders|
                                        |and v. 7 begins with a coordinating conjunction, it stands to reason that, at least for the churches|
                                        |Titus was dealing with, elders were bishops and vice-versa. This supports the theory that the ancient|
                                        |church was originally run by elders but later on transitioned to one which was run by bishops instead.|
     B                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">”Cretans are always liars, vicious brutes, and fat blimps”</char>…From the sounds of|
                                        |it, this prophet was parroting an outrageously false, negative ethnic stereotype about Cretans, which|
                                        |the prophet categorically applies to all Cretans. Paul is vehemently condemning that kind of language.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |<char style="it">clean</char>…Also: <char style="it">pure</char>. Paul’s usage of clean and defiled here|
                                        |is a metaphor to the OT concepts of clean and unclean, concepts which are deeply rooted in the Law of|
                                        |Moses and touch all the temple rituals and quite a lot of other things. Once something was defiled (tainted),|
                                        |it could no longer be used in the temple service. Care had to be taken to keep or maintain people or|
                                        |things in a state of cleanness.|
     C                FOOTNOTES_NORMAL: |The metaphor presented here is that a person who’s clean is one who’s pure in mind and spirit, and everything|
                                        |that person handles is automatically clean. A person who’s pure will look at any fact, teaching, philosophy,|
                                        |etc. and come up with practical applications, anecdotes, life-lessons, analogies, etc. which are pure,|
                                        |meaning they’ll support or complement Christian truths, principles, and values. But anyone who’s defiled,|
                                        |any fact, teaching, philosophy, etc. will ultimately lead to something twisted, to the point of contradicting|
                                        |Christian truths, principles, and values.|
